Homebrew Compilation

1 Rules Patches

1.1 New Rule: Skill Specialisations

Everyone with a bit of skill has a little something extra they can contribute outside of combat. To represent this, almost all characters gain access to a few Skill Specialisations based on the number of skills their Class gives:

Table 1.1: Number of Skill Specialisations
Class Skills Skill Specialisations
3 0
4 0
5 1
6 3
7 5
8 5
9 5

Each Skill Specialisation represents a specific facet of the out-of-combat applications of a given skill that you are especially good at. When you use that Skill for the Specialised purpose outside of combat (the DM can let you have the bonus in combat but you had better be doing something really cool with it), you gain a +2 bonus to the check, plus an additional +1 at levels 5, 10, 15 and 20.

You gain choose from the following options (there are no options for Ride or Stealth because they really aren’t very nuanced):

1.1.1 Athletics Specialisations

Climb: For climbing tricky surfaces to traverse the environment - not for the in combat thing where you become so good at climbing you essentially fly.

Swim: For swimming and holding your breath underwater - the most likely option to end up being relevant in combat.

Sprint: For when you are making an Athletics check to just go really fast (including in the Parkour skill game).

1.1.2 Acrobatics Specialisations

Balance: For crossing a rickety bridge, a slippy mountain ridge, or surviving a fall from those or similar.

Jump: For when you are trying to jump high or far - again not for the in combat thing where you jump so high that you essentially fly.

Tumble: For general feats of pure acrobatics, including parkour (and, indeed, Parkour in the skill game).

1.1.3 Larceny Specialisations

Disable Device: For disarming traps, unpicking locks, and engaging in industrial sabotage.

Sleight of Hand: For cheating at games of chance and engaging in a bit of classic pickpocketing.

Forgery: For when you need to make something written or drawn look like something really specific.

Disguise: For when you need yourself and others to look like something really specific (or specifically nonspecific).

Appraise: For working out the street value of the latest piece of loot.

1.1.4 Vigour Specialisations

Concentration: For maintaining your presence of mind, and even hold on a ritual spell, in adverse conditions.

Alcoholism: For when you are making one of those most honourable Vigour checks: Checking for if you can hold your drink!

1.1.5 Arcana Specialisations

Use Magic Device: For interpreting Scrolls, using Staves, and otherwise getting uncooperative magical items to cooperate.

Decypher Code: Many ancient magics come in the form of strange glyphs, but your specialisation at interpreting these also means you’re pretty good at normal cryptography.

Identify Static Magic: This isn’t for identifying cast spells or magic items, but rather for when there is a complex magical puzzle in a ruin or some kind of ancient enchantment you need to discern the meaning and purpose of.

1.1.6 Engineering Specialisations

Architecture: For understanding the properties of buildings (including buildings that also happen to be dungeons and maybe have secret doors and the like).

Use Rope: It’s simple, but this is for when you are using rope for all of its many purposes - tying up a captive, keeping the party tied together as you scale a cliff, rigging up some weird apparatus, etc.

Construction: For when you are building stuff, be it mundane or a [Construct] with a capital [].

1.1.7 Geography Specialisations

Discern Direction: For when you’re lost and need to figure out how to get where you want to go.

Local: For when you want information on the nearby towns and villages that only a real social scientist would know.

The Planes: For understanding Elementals, Outsiders, and the odd realities they call home.

1.1.8 History Specialisations

Nobility and Royalty: To know specifically about the movers and shakers of the quasi-medieval world.

Religion: To recognise Holy Symbols and remember the doctrines of deities both obscure and well-known.

Language: To understand ancient language or to apply that knowledge to identify a modern one.

1.1.9 Medicine Specialisations

Humanoid Anatomy: For when you’re being asked some specific question about how Humans, Dwarves, Elves, etc… Well, how they work.

Heal Diseases: For when you’re applying your Medicine skills to the more long-lasting sort of affliction.

Heal Lethal Wounds: For when you’re specifically trying to revive someone who has been pronounced medically [Dead].

1.1.10 Nature Specialisations

Weather: For understanding and predicting meteorological phenomena.

Tracking: For following the trail of an animal, or applying that skill to track something more intelligent.

Handle Animal: For befriending and sympathetically understanding animals.

1.1.11 Perception Specialisations

Sense Motive: For when you’re carefully observing someone’s tells to work out what they’re really trying to achieve.

1.1.12 Bluff Specialisations

Gather Information: For making the ‘just go around and bullshit with people until you steer them onto a relevant conversation topic’ method of information gathering more effective.

1.1.13 Diplomacy Specialisations

Perform: For when you’re doing a musical, poetic, or otherwise artistic performance to impress or to make money.

1.1.14 Intimidate Specialisations

Interrogation: For when you’re explicitly trying to get information out of someone you’ve cornered, or making the check in an Interrogation skill game.

1.2 New Rule: [Guild] Feats

Characters using a Racial class can no longer use their free multiclass (they just replace one track of their chosen base class with their Racial track - they can still choose Shaman, though).

Instead, whenever you take a feat with the [Guild] descriptor, you may swap one of your existing tracks for any other track. You can even take two [Guild] feats at level 1 if you’re crazy like that. This might make Guild Initiation useless, but note that it can still be taken in place of one of your Racial bonus feats, so may be helpful to a character with no racial bonus [Guild] feats who wishes to double-multiclass.

The following vanilla feats are now [Guild] feats:

  • By Will Sustained
  • Chatty Bugger
  • Esoteric Adept (can also take this if you use it to swap into a Spellcasting track)
  • Small Concessions
  • The Sun Grows Dim
  • Troubleshooter
  • Sinister Sinews

For reference, the other [Guild] feats are:

  • Curiosity
  • Iocane Powder
  • Know a Guy
  • Mister World-Mind
  • Open-Minded
  • Pick a God and Pray!
  • Subtle Knife

1.3 New Rule: [Brutal] Dice

Instead of dealing bonus damage, weapons with the [Brutal] property now (as they did back in the Ancient Times) change the damage dice you roll for the weapon. The dice improve as you level up, according to the table below:

Table 1.2: Damage Dice
Level Brutal 0 Brutal 1 Brutal 2 Brutal 3
1 1d6 1d8 1d10 1d12
2 1d6 1d8 1d10 1d10+1d4
3 1d6 1d8 1d8+1d4 1d10+1d4
4 1d6 1d8 1d8+1d4 1d12+1d4
5 1d6 1d8 1d8+1d4 1d12+1d4
6 1d6 1d6+1d4 1d10+1d4 1d12+1d6
7 1d6 1d6+1d4 1d10+1d4 1d12+1d6
8 1d6 1d6+1d4 1d10+1d4 1d12+1d8
9 1d6 1d6+1d4 1d10+1d6 1d12+1d8
10 1d6 1d6+1d4 1d10+1d6 1d12+1d10
11 1d6 1d6+1d4 1d10+1d6 1d12+1d10
12 1d6 1d8+1d4 1d10+1d8 2d12
13 1d6 1d8+1d4 1d10+1d8 2d12
14 1d6 1d8+1d4 1d10+1d8 1d12+1d8+1d6
15 1d6 1d8+1d4 1d12+1d8 1d12+1d8+1d6
16 1d6 1d8+1d4 1d12+1d8 2d12+1d4
17 1d6 1d8+1d4 1d12+1d8 2d12+1d4
18 1d6 1d8+1d6 1d12+1d10 2d12+1d6
19 1d6 1d8+1d6 1d12+1d10 2d12+1d6
20 1d6 1d8+1d6 1d12+1d10 2d12+1d8

The Weaponised Feat now reads:

1.3.1 Weaponised

Your attacks are reliably effective
Prerequisite: BAB +6, KOM of +5 or more
Benefit: You treat all d4s and d6s you roll for your weapon (not for additional dice e.g. from [Precision] damage) as their maximum result. If your KOM is 6 or more, you treat d8s as their maximum result, if 8 or more you treat d10s as their maximum result, and if 10 or more you treat d12s as their maximum result.

2 Alternative Class Options

2.1 Barbarian

2.1.1 Path of the Wild

Special: You may take this track as a Barbarian’s Path of War.

You are touched by the power of the Feywild. Maybe you have been permanently changed by time spent in the Fey’s realm. Perhaps you were touched by a Fey as a child. Perhaps the Queen of a Court has chosen you for an unknowable purpose. In any case, you can draw on the unpredictable powers of the Feywild, causing a surge of indescribable energy around you, your skin to change colour and your face to distort, and a variety of magical effects to happen.

1st Circle - Wild ShiftSU: As a swift action, when you are not already Shifted, you may start to Wild Shift. Your Shift lasts for three [Rounds], or you can end it as a free action.

While Shifted you gain +15 to movement speed and +2 to saving throws. When you start to Shift, roll a d4 and gain the respectie bonus:

  • 1: Your arms are shrouded in Shadowfell energy, and your melee attacks deal energy damage with the [Negative] descriptor and deal an additional 1d10 damage. You gain temporary hit points equal to the amount you roll on the d10 which stack up to 10.
  • 2: You are surrounded by a shroud of energy which grants +2 to AC and deals magical damage equal to your level to each creature the first time it attacks you each [Round].
  • 3: Plant life grows around you, making all terrain in [Close] range of you difficult for opponents. If a creature ends turn within that difficult terrain, they are [Entangled] until the end of their next turn or until they leave the difficult terrain.
  • 4: When you enter the Shift, a beam of light lances from your chest in a 5 ft wide line out to 60 ft. All creatures in the line take 2d8 [Force] damage and are [Blinded] for one [Round] (a DC 10 + ½ your level + your Con modifier Fortitude save negates the [Blinded]).

2nd Circle – Magical ReservesSU: While Shifted, you can restore magical power to an ally in [Melee] range with a standard action using your own being. Choose either a spell slot or a per [Encounter] use of a spell, spell-like or supernatural ability that ally has used up. Take damage and [HP reduction] equal to five times the circle of that ability. It is then restored. The [HP reduction] from this ability lasts until the end of the [Scene].

3rd Circle – Pure ChaosSU: Your bonus to speed when Shifted increases to 30 ft and your bonus to saving throws increases to +4. Now, roll a d6 at the start of your Shift. The first four results are upgraded as follows, and a new two possibilities are added:

  • 1: The additional damage increases to 1d10 for every odd numbered circle you have in Path of the Wild, you gain temporary hit points equal to the total of the d10 rolls, which stack up to 10 per circle you have in Path of the Wild.
  • 2: The AC bonus increases to the number of circles you have in Path of the Wild, and the damage increases to twice your level.
  • 3: Creatures that end their turn within your [Close] range take a penalty to speed, after the effect of Entangled, equal to 5 per circle you have in Path of the Wild.
  • 4: The line increases to 200 ft long and 10 ft wide and the damage to 1d8 per two levels you have.
  • 5: Up to three spectral clones of you appear, each within your [Close] range. These clones cannot move, and cannot be the target of any attacks. On your turn, each clone may make a single melee attack, as if it were you. Your clones cannot target the same creature.
  • 6: Your allies in [Medium] range hear the wistful notes of a Satyr’s flute and may add 1d4 to all their d20 rolls.

4th Circle – Arcane RebukeSU: Any creature who forces you to make a saving throw due to an ability of theirs takes 1d6 magical damage per circle you have in Path of the Wild.

5th Circle – Breath of the WildSU: While Shifted, your movement speed bonus increases to 45 ft, and your saving throws bonus increases to +6.

6th Circle – Wild at HeartSU: While Shifted you gain a 20% [Miss chance] and never provoke attacks of opportunity. Your [Miss chance] cannot be reduced by any means.

7th Circle – Infinite ChaosSU: You can have the effects of any number of Shifts active at once, though they expire at the end of the [Encounter]. Your bonus to speed when Shifted increases to 60 and your bonus to saves increases to +8.

2.1.2 Path of Savagery

Special: You may take this track in place of Path of Destruction in the Barbarian class

Some Barbarians forgo the brute strength techniques of destruction for more finesse. Of course, it’s Barbarian-style finesse. So it just means hitting someone with two weapons instead. And trying to hit vital parts instead of just hitting really hard.

1st Circle – Crush Your EnemiesEX: When you score a critical hit, your target takes a -3 penalty to attack and AC until the start of your next turn.

2nd Circle – Wolf Fang StrikeEX: You can always wield two weapons at a time. Once per [Round] you may make an attack action with a -2 penalty to attack rolls. Then, one attack at the highest bonus becomes two attacks, one with each weapon you are wielding. The second attack may only be a Melee attack and only deals its base damage plus your KOM. Effects other than those of a critical hit that activate as a result of this second hit do not activate.

3rd Circle – See Them DrivenEX: You gain a [Bonus Attack]. You gain a +1 fury bonus to attack and damage whenever you score a critical hit. This stacks up to the number of circles you have in Path of Savagery, but ends once you start your turn after having not scored a critical hit in the last turn. This bonus stacks with any bonuses from Path of War, but with no other fury bonuses (as normal).

4th Circle – Fountain of BloodEX: Once per [Encounter], when you reduce an opponent to 0 HP or less with a melee attack, you may deal an additional 3d6 damage. If you do, and the target dies as a result, all opponents in your [Close] range of that creature are [Nauseated] for one [Round]. A successful Fortitude save (DC 10 + ½ your level + your KOM) reduces this to [Sickened].

5th Circle – Hear the LamentationsEX: Choose one of the following abilities (your choice is permanent):

  • Pouncing Charge: When you make a Charge action you can make a full attack at the end of the Charge, but only the first attack benefits from the +2 bonus.
  • Flesh Ripper: Your critical threat range on melee attacks increases to include the next four numbers. This cannot cause your range to increase past the lower bound of 12.

6th Circle – Tiger Fang StrikeEX: When you use Wolf Fang Strike, you may take a further -2 penalty to attack. If you do, you may make a second extra attack (on your [Bonus Attack]), this follows the same rules as the Wolf Fang Strike extra attack.

7th Circle – Girallon Flesh RipEX: Your constant attacks rend at your foes’ flesh. At the end of your turn, all creatures you have hit twice take an additional 2d8 physical damage, this ignores all [Damage reduction] and [Resistance]. Those you have hit 4 times instead take 6d8. Those you have hit 6 times instead take 12d8.

2.1.3 Path of Anarchy

Special: You may take this track in place of Path of the Ancestors in the Barbarian class

Lots of Barbarians rage as a means to an end. Getting very angry fills them with powerful hormones, which allows them to smash their enemies effectively. But perhaps more dangerous are the Barbarians who get angry for a reason, an ideology regarding the need for life outside of existing structures and societies. As well as a motivation, this conviction gives Anarchs the power to draw upon chaos magic to act as both sword and shield.

1st Circle – Throwing the DiceSU: You start each [Scene] with a single d6 in your Anarchy Dice. The first time each [Round] that you hit with or are hit by an attack (once for each), or any ability which does damage which requires an attack roll, roll all of your Anarchy Dice. Add the result to the damage roll if you were the attacker, and remove it from the damage roll if you were the target.

Whenever you roll the highest value on an Anarchy Die, it increases in size by one (e.g. from d6 to d8, or d8 to d10). Whenever you roll the lowest value on an Anarchy Die, it reduces in size by one (e.g. from a d6 to a d4). When you roll a 1 on a d4, you instead lose the Die. When you roll a 12 on a d12, it instead becomes two d4s.

Three times per [Scene], when you are not in combat and have no Anarchy Dice, you gain the Anarchy Dice you started the [Scene] with.

2nd Circle – Roll the Dice Just One More TimeSU: You start each [Scene] with three d6s as Anarchy Dice.

As a free action during your turn, you may reduce the size of one of your Anarchy Dice by one. When you do, you may change your size by one stage (i.e. from [Small] to [Average] or from [Large] to [Huge]), or [Teleport] up to your movement speed to any unoccupied space you have line of sight to.

3rd Circle – Wings of FreedomSU: You start each [Scene] with four d8s as Anarchy Dice.

A number of times per [Encounter] equal to the number of natural 20s you have rolled in the [Encounter] minus the number of natural 1s you have rolled in the [Encounter], as a swift action, increase the size of one of your Anarchy Dice by one.

As a free action on your turn, you may reduce the size of one of your Anarchy Dice by one to gain the Fly, Swim or Burrow movement mode until the end of the [Encounter].

4th Circle – Introduce a Little AnarchySU: You start each [Scene] with five d8s as Anarchy Dice.

As a free action on your turn, you may reduce the size of each of your Anarchy Dice to cause all effects and benefits of a Lesser Item you can see within [Close] range to end until the end of the [Encounter].

5th Circle – Chaos ControlSU: You start each [Scene] with six d8s as Anarchy Dice.

When you [Teleport] with the 2nd Circle ability you now [Warp]. You ignore all negative effects of a size category you become with the 2nd Circle ability.

The 4th Circle ability can now target Greater Items.

6th Circle – Agent of ChaosSU: You start each [Scene] with eight d8s as Anarchy Dice.

The first time each [Encounter] you make a successful save against an effect that would normally have a lesser effect on a successful save (such as a spell with a save of “Fortitude half”), you instead ignore the effect entirely. You gain an additional use of this ability every time you roll a natural 20 on a saving throw.

7th Circle – Anarchy in the Outer PlanesSU: You start each [Scene] with ten d10s as Anarchy Dice.

When you die, roll a d12. On a 10, 11 or 12 you stay dead. On a 7, 8 or 9 you survive at 1 hit point and this ability will not work for the duration of the [Encounter]. On a 4, 5 or 6 you survive and return to half your maximum hit points and this ability will not work for the rest of the [Scene]. On a 2 or 3 you survive at return to your maximum hit points with a new d12 in your Anarchy Dice and this ability will not work for the rest of the [Scene]. A 1 has the same effect as a 2 or a 3 but does not cancel this ability for the rest of the [Scene].

2.2 Monk

2.2.1 Discipline of the Kirin

Special: You may take this track in place of Discipline of the Serpent in the Monk class

There are some Monks who forgo the precise strikes of the Discipline of the Serpent for a different style, one where they harness their ki to both enhance their strikes and fire blasts of force energy. One such group is the Fistbeard Monestary, who go one step further by harnessing their ki through the medium of the Beard.

1st Circle – Fist of the North StarSU: Your Unarmed Strike gains [Arcane] and three other weapon properties of your choice, other than [Barbed], [Distant], [Hold-out] or [Quick-draw]. You can enchant your Unarmed Strike as a Lesser Item with enchantments as normal for a magic weapon of its type. When you gain your 4th Circle in Discipline of the Kirin, re-design your unarmed strike as a Greater item, and when you gain your 6th Circle, redesign it as a Relic. Though your Unarmed Strike possesses the [Arcane] property, it itself is a supernatural ability, and attacks with it benefit from magic weapon item bonuses to attack, magic item enchantments that trigger on a hit, and the [Brutal] property.

2nd Circle – Fist of FurySU: You gain access to the following special abilities:

  • Hadoken: You may replace one attack made as part of your attack action with a ranged attack at the same attack bonus as the replaced attack out to [Close] range. On a hit, this attack does damage as your unarmed strike, but with the [Force] descriptor and ignoring all damage reduction and [Resistance].
  • Badoken: Once per [Round], as a swift action or part of a move action, you may fire a small ball of energy, dealing damage equal to your Wis modifier to one opponent in [Close] range.
  • Falcon Punch: As a standard action, and only as the last action you take in a [Round], you may start to charge a Falcon Punch. The first time each opponent deals damage to you while you charge a Falcon Punch, you must make a Fortitude or Will save (DC 10 + ½ attacker’s level + attacker’s KOM) or lose the charge. If you retain the charge, as your first action next turn you make use a Falcon Punch as a standard action. This is a melee attack with a +3 bonus which deals damage as your unarmed strike, but it is energy damage with the [Fire] descriptor. After damage is rolled and all modifiers are added, triple the damage done.

3rd Circle – Fist of White LotusSU: As a swift action, you may either choose a spell-like ability or spend a spell slot and choose a spell which has a Target listing of a single creature of circle equal to or lower than the spent spell slot to charge your Unarmed Strike. On a hit, you may choose to discharge your Unarmed Strike. If you do, you may cast the spell or spell-like ability as a [Surge] effect. If the spell or ability requires an attack roll, use the result of your Unarmed Strike attack as the result of the attack roll, if the ability affects multiple squares or creatures, one of those must be the target of the Unarmed Strike attack. You may only charge your Unarmed Strike with one ability or spell at a time.

4th Circle – Fist of LegendSU: You gain the following improvements to your abilities:

  • Hadoken: Hadoken is now out to [Medium] range, and always attacks with your highest attack bonus.
  • Badoken: You can now use Badoken an unlimited amount of times per [Round]
  • Falcon Punch: If an opponent provokes an attack of opportunity from you while you are charging a Falcon Punch, you may make the Falcon Punch as an attack of opportunity.

5th Circle – Fist of ZenSU: Once per [Round], you may replace an attack in your attack action with one of the following abilities:

  • Shinku Hadoken: You make an attack with the [Volley] descriptor at the same attack bonus as the replaced attack. This applies to all enemies in a line out to your [Close] range and 10 ft wide.
  • Metsu Hadoken: You make an attack with the [Volley] descriptor at the same attack bonus as the replaced attack. This applies to all enemies in a 20 ft radius within your [Medium] range.

6th Circle – Quivering PalmSU: Once per [Encounter], as a standard action you may make a melee attack which deals normal damage and forces a Fortitude save (DC 10 +1/2 your level + your Wis modifier). If the target fails a Fortitude save, they gain a charge of Quivering Palm, as you disrupt their ki. As an immediate action, you may dispel this charge to deal 6 points of energy damage with the [Force] descriptor per level and cause the target to be [Dazed] for one [Round]. This is a [Death] effect. Charges of Quivering Palm disappear at the end of the [Scene].

7th Circle – Atomic Falcon PunchSU: When you start to charge a Falcon Punch, you can instead charge an Atomic Falcon Punch. At the start of your next turn, instead of using a Falcon Punch you must use all your actions in the [Round] to continue charging the Atomic Falcon Punch. If you still retain the charge as the first action in the next turn you may use the Atomic Falcon Punch as a standard action. This is a melee attack with a +10 bonus which deals damage as a Falcon Punch, but tripled again.

2.2.2 Discipline of the Eagle

Special: You may take this track in place of Discipline of the Serpent in the Monk class

The pistoleros of the Lorado frontier call it the Discipline of the Eagle. The bravos of Fiora call it Hand-et-Bow. The gnomes of Baccain call it Gun Kata. The Kheru hunters of Adissa call it the Way of the Purger. In all cases, it is the art of wielding ranged weapons in pitched melee battles to brutal and stylish effect.

1st Circle – Gun-FuEX: You do not provoke attacks of opportunity from using ranged attacks in [Melee] range except from the target of the attack. You can use the Mirror Shot combat manoeuvre.

  • Mirror Shot: As a standard action, make an attack action. The first attack, if it is a ranged attack, can be made against two creatures simultaneously, dealing normal damage to both, if both enemies and you are in a single straight line, with you in the middle.

2nd Circle – EquilibriumEX: You can use the Dodge Shot and Roll Shot combat manoeuvres.

  • Dodge Shot: As a free action before you make an attack action, you may choose a number up to your Base Attack Bonus. If all attacks in the attack action are ranged attacks, you take a penalty to attack rolls in the action equal to the chosen number, and gain a bonus to saving throws equal to the chosen number until the start of your next turn.
  • Roll Shot: As a free action during an attack action in which all attacks are ranged attacks, you can move up to 10 ft without provoking attacks of opportunity and fall [Prone]. While [Prone] from this effect, you are not [Flat-footed] against [Melee] attacks and instead gain a +2 bonus to AC against them (you are still [Covered] from ranged attacks like normal). Getting up from this [Prone] position provokes attacks of opportunity as normal.

3rd Circle – Gun ControlEX: You can use the Shatter Shot and Bounce Shot combat manoeuvres. You no longer provoke any attacks of opportunity for using ranged attacks in [Melee] range.

  • Shatter Shot: As a standard action, make a single ranged attack roll. On a hit, dispel up to two magical effects on the target of circle equal to or lower than the number of circles you have in Discipline of the Eagle. The target also loses any [Miss chance] they have for two [Rounds]. A Reflex save (DC 10 + 1/2 your level + your KOM) halves the number of dispelled effects and prevents [Miss chance] loss.
  • Bounce Shot: Once per [Round], when making an attack in an attack action where every attack is a ranged attack, if you have line of sight and line of effect to a solid wall you may choose a space in a straight, unobstructed line from a point on that wall you have line of sight and line of effect to. For the purposes of the attack, you have line of sight and line of effect to that space (you still can’t actually see it, so you will need to just know if there is anything in the space to attack).

4th Circle – Wings of FreedomEX: If you move a distance equal to your Speed, you ignore any attacks of opporunity while moving, can move through spaces occupied by any opponents, and can move over or through any obstacle through a combination of sick flips, wall running, and the like.

5th Circle – Gun KataEX: You can use the Kata Flurry and Called Shot combat manoeuvres.

  • Kata Flurry: As a standard action, make two ranged attacks against each opponent who you are in the [Melee] range of.
  • Called Shot: As a standard action, or once per [Round] replacing an attack in an attack action, make a ranged attack and choose one of the following additional effects. If a creature makes a save against any of these effects, they are treated as having made the save against all subsequent uses of the effect for the [Encounter]:
    • Head: Deal additional damage equal to four times your level. A Reflex save halves this damage and prevents it from reducing the target below 1 hit point. This is a [Death] effect.
    • Legs: On a hit the target falls [Prone], starts [Bleeding] and is [Slowed] until the end of the [Encounter]. A Reflex save prevents the [Slowed] condition.
    • Arms: On a hit the target drops their currently wielded weapon, starts [Bleeding] and treats their KOM as 0 as long as they are [Bleeding]. A Reflex save prevents the [Bleeding] condition.
    • Vitals: On a hit the target is [Exhausted] and [Battered] for the [Encounter]. A Reflex save prevents both conditions.

6th Circle – Neo CortexEX: As an immediate action once per [Encounter], you may gain a +10 bonus to AC and Reflex saves against all attacks and abilities originating from a wedge out to your [Long] range which you choose on using this ability until the end of your next turn.

7th Circle – Fastest Gun in the WestEX: As an immediate action once per [Encounter], make a standard action which must be used for attacks or combat manoeuvres. All opponents are [Flat-footed] and lose their KDM bonus to AC against attacks in this action.

2.2.3 Discipline of the Monkey

Special: You may take this track in place of Discipline of the Crane in the Monk class

Many Monks of a more chaotic bent eschew the considered and fluid movements of the Crane for a more erratic approach, making unpredictable moves to confuse their opponents, and employing strange manoeuvres and throws to mess up the battlefield. Save DCs for this track are 10 + ½ your level + your Wis modifier.

1st Circle – Mighty ThrowEX: As a move action after an opponent fails a save against a Trip attempt you make, you may throw them as a move action. When thrown, you move the opponent up to 10 ft per circle you have in Discipline of the Monkey. The opponent takes damage equal to your KOM for every 10 ft they move. This damage ignores [Damage reduction] and [Resistance]. The DC of saves against your Trip manoeuvre is now 10 + ½ your level + your Wis modifier (unless you have the Internal Principles ability, which overwrites this).

2nd Circle – Monkey BusinessEX: You are automatically aware whenever an opponent you can see uses the Charge manoeuvre. Twice per [Encounter], as an immediate action, you may force target opponent activating a Charge that moves to within your [Melee] range to end the charge within your [Melee] range, move them 5 ft in any direction (this provokes attacks of opportunity), and have them forgo any remaining attacks in the Charge. Also, you gain access to the following additional Combat Manoeuvre, this benefits from additional damage from External Techniques if you have that ability:

  • Clever Positioning: As a standard action, you make a single melee attack that deals normal damage. On a hit, the target swaps places with you and becomes [Flat-footed]. A successful Reflex save negates this effect. The movement from the swap does not provoke attacks of opportunity.

3rd Circle – Ajar GateEX: Once per [Round], when you provoke an attack of opportunity you may make it a Feigned Opening as a free action. If an opponent hits you with an attack of opportunity from a Feigned Opening, you may immediately make a single melee attack back. If an opponent misses an attack of opportunity from a Feigned Opening, they provoke an attack of opportunity.

4th Circle – Monkey See, Monkey DoEX: Twice per [Encounter], as an immediate action when an opponent within your [Melee] range moves, you may move the same distance as them in the same direction(s). This movement does not provoke an attack of opportunity. The manoeuvres you gain from this track can be used with Ceaseless Flow if you have that ability.

5th Circle – Ballista ThrowEX: When you use Mighty Throw, if you throw an opponent into another opponent, the thrown creature takes double damage from the throw, and the creature it was thrown into also takes the original damage from the throw.

6th Circle – Monkeying AroundEX: You gain access to the following special Combat Manoeuvres, these benefit from additional damage from External Techniques if you have that ability:

  • Broken Shield: As a standard action, you make a single melee attack that deals normal damage. If the attack hits that target becomes [Flat-footed] and loses the benefit of any two sources of [Resistance] or [Damage reduction] of your choice. A successful Will save negates this effect.
  • Hydra Slaying Strike: As a standard action, you make a single melee attack that deals normal damage. If the attack hits the target must make a Fortitude save or be unable to make iterative attacks and [Bonus attacks] on their next turn.

7th Circle – Tornado ThrowEX: Once per [Encounter], as a standard action, move up to your speed without provoking any attacks of opportunity. For each opponent that is in your [Melee] range at any point in the movement you may make a Trip attack against them. You may use Mighty Throw on every opponent that fails the save against the Trip without using a move action.

2.2.4 Discipline of the Panda

Special: You may take this track in place of Discipline of the Crane in the Monk class. You cannot take this as your Slow track by any means.

Beyond training, there is Zen. Monks with natural talent but no trained ability often find it easier to simply let go of the illusion of control in battle, and go with the flow. Named after a famous Ailurian master from the Tai Mountains of Azujin, the Discipline of the Panda teaches unpredictability and inner peace.

1st Circle – The Water SettledEX: If you end your turn having taken no actions that you took the previous turn, you become [Zen] until the end of your next turn. Making a attack action counts as the same as an attack action against any target, as does moving even if it is to a different place. Using the remainder of a partial move action to move counts as the same action as using the remainder of a different partial move action, but is different to only moing with a move action. Using a Manoeuvre counts as a different action to an attack action or a different Manoeuvre. Free actions still count towards becoming [Zen], but using a free action to talk does not.

While you are [Zen], you gain a deflection bonus to AC equal to 1 plus the number of circles you have in Disicpline of the Panda.

2nd Circle – The Mind ClearEX: While [Zen], you gain a bonus to the DC of saves against your combat maneovures equal to the deflection bonus you gain to AC.

Once per [Encounter], if you make a successful Fortitude or Will saving throw against an offensive action that normally deals half damage on a successful save while you are [Zen], you may instead take no damage.

3rd Circle – There Are No AccidentsEX: While [Zen], you gain [Resistance] to all damage. This does not stack with other sources of [Resistance] or [Lesser resistance].

4th Circle – Yesterday is History, Tomorrow is a MysteryEX: After making an attack roll for a combat manoeuvre, you may make iterative attacks. These iterative attacks do not count as the same action for the purpose of becoming [Zen] as long as they were made after different combat manoeuvres. Using Ceaseless Flow to replace these attacks with other combat manouvres on consecutive turns does count as the same aciton for the purpose of becoming [Zen].

5th Circle – There Is No Secret IngredientEX: Once per [Scene], you can freely change your Feats and your Slow track with one hour of effort.

6th Circle – More Than Who You AreEX: Whenever you become [Zen], you gain 25 temporary hit points.

7th Circle – The Dragon WarriorEX: You gain [Immunity] to [Stunned], [Dazed], [Battered] and [Binding] effects.

2.3 Paladin

2.3.1 Cleric Spellcasting

Special: You may take this track as your Paladin Dedication, in which case it becomes your Fast track and Judgement becomes your Medium track.

You cast spells drawn from the cleric spell list, detailed in the Spells section. Your Wisdom modifier is your Spellcasting Ability Modifier (SAM) for this track. The DC for your spells is equal to 10 + ½ your character level + your Spellcasting Ability Modifier. You can only cast a certain number of spells of each spell level in a [Scene]. That number is noted on the “Spells per [Scene] by Circle” section of the table below. You also receive bonus spells per [Scene] for having a high Spellcasting Ability Modifier.

You can only cast spells that you know. You gain an additional three spells known every time you gain a circle in this track. Any time that you level up, you can unlearn a single spell and learn a new spell of the same level. You cannot learn spells of a level you cannot cast. You may use an available spell slot of a circle to cast any spell you know of that circle or lower.

Table 2.1: Cleric Spells
Level 1st Circle 2nd Circle 3rd Circle 4th Circle 5th Circle 6th Circle 7th Circle
1 2 – – – – – –
2 3 – – – – – –
3 3 2 – – – – –
4 4 3 – – – – –
5 4 3 – – – – –
6 5 4 2 – – – –
7 5 4 3 – – – –
8 5 5 3 – – – –
9 5 5 4 2 – – –
10 5 5 4 3 – – –
11 5 5 5 3 – – –
12 5 5 5 4 2 – –
13 5 5 5 4 3 – –
14 5 5 5 5 3 – –
15 5 5 5 5 4 2 –
16 5 5 5 5 4 3 –
17 5 5 5 5 5 3 –
18 5 5 5 5 5 4 2
19 5 5 5 5 5 4 3
20 5 5 5 5 5 5 3

2.3.2 Pain – The Seven Circles of Suffering

Special: A Paladin can choose Pain as their Oath or Dedication.

There exist some factions and individuals who war and fight not for death, but simply to inflict pain. Sometimes, this is done only for power, offering the excruciation up to something higher that may feed on it, but often the entity itself is twisted and sadistic, gaining pleasure and finding sustenance on the pain of others. Whatever the purpose, such creatures are fuelled by torment and suffering, using it to bolster themselves and allies, in search of more tender victims.

1st Circle – No Pain, No GainSLA: As a standard action, you can select one enemy in [Close] range to be marked as a [Victim]. This mark lasts for two [Rounds].

Whenever a [Victim] is hit by an action or ability that requires an attack roll, or fails a saving throw, that [Victim], [Suffers]. Whenever each creature within [Long] range [Suffers] for the first time each [round], counting from the start of your turn, you may heal one ally within [Close] range of that target by 1d4 per circle of Cult of Pain you possess, plus your KOM. Whenever a creature within [Long] range [Suffers] after the first time each [Round], you may heal one ally within [Close] range of that target by an amount equal to your level.

2nd Circle – Enthusiastic MartyrSU: You may always have yourself counted as a [Victim], but always count as having [Suffered] Previously in the round, and can only target other allies for healing from the No Pain No Gain ability.

3rd Circle – The Pain TrainSLA: When activating the No Pain, No Gain ability to mark an enemy as a [Victim], you may target two enemies with a single standard action.

Additionally, you have [Lesser Resistance] to physical damage originating from [Victims].

4th Circle – Sado-MasochismSLA: Whenever you activate the No Pain, No Gain ability to heal an ally, you gain temporary hit points equal to your KOM, and these temporary hit points stack. For each successive time this ability activates in a [Round], the amount of temporary hp you receive decreases by 1.

Whenever you mark an enemy as a [Victim], that enemy remains marked for 3 rounds.

5th Circle – Max PainSU: Whenever you heal with the No Pain, No Gain ability, you heal the target an additional 3 hit points for each [Victim] that has previously [Suffered] in the same round, counting from the start of your turn.

Additionally, at the start of your turn, you and all allies within [Close] range heal for an amount equal to the number of [Victims] that have [Suffered] since the start of your last turn.

6th Circle – The Highest PleasureSU: Whenever a [Victim] who is an opponent [Suffers] within [Medium] range, that target takes additional damage equal to your KOM, and becomes [Shaken] for one round.

You gain [Greater Resistance] to physical damage originating from an enemy [Victim] that has [Suffered] in the same round. This resistance replaces the [Lesser Resistance] gained from The Pain Train ability, unless that [Victim] has not [Suffered].

7th Circle – Exalted ExcrutiatorSLA: Once per [Scene], as a standard action, you may select one creature you have previously marked as a [Victim]. That creature, wherever they are, becomes a [Victim] until the end of the [Encounter], and whenever that target takes an amount of damage, you may heal yourself or an ally within [Medium] range of yourself for an equal amount. This healing does not require an action, but this ability expires at the end of the encounter.

2.3.3 Twilight – The Seven Circles of Sanctuary

Special: A Paladin can choose Twilight as their Oath or Dedication.

Twilight, the transition between night and day. The time when the fading light gives its last protection to the people, and when warriors go out to combat the horrors of the dark. Worshippers of deities of protection, bravery, and even travel and sanctuary can all benefit from the supernatural protection of twilight. This power grants vigilance, protection, and healing.

1st Circle – Vigilance of NightEX: At the start of battle, you may reroll your Initiative check (you must take the new result), once per [Scene] you may allow an ally to reroll their Initiative check. You and the most recent ally you allowed to reroll their Initiative have Darkvision.

2nd Circle – Twilight SanctuarySU: As a move action, create a spread with radius 30 ft centred within your [Close] range and lasts one [Round] and generates illumination. All allies ending turn in the spread heal hit points equal to your level + your KDM, and one [Mind-affecting] effect affecting them ends.

3rd Circle – Step of the BraveEX: You gain the Fly movement mode and [Immunity] to [Fear].

4th Circle – Dusk’s SanctuarySU: With 30 minutes of effort, you can transport yourself and up to nine allies into an extradimensional space. This area is a 20 ft radius dome with basic food and drink supplies and bedrolls for ten [Average] sized creatures. You can remain there until the end of the [Scene], at which point you return to where you entered the extradimensional space from. All creatures who rested in the sanctuary have [Immunity] to [Fear] for the next [Scene], and start the [Scene] with temporary hit points equal to three times your level + your KDM.

5th Circle – Shelter of the StarsSU: Your Twilight Sanctuary grants all allies inside [Greater resistance] to [Negative] damage, [Lesser resistance] to all other damage and [Immunity] to [HP reduction] (unless it is caused by themselves). Also, the first creature each [Encounter] to die inside your Twilight Sanctuary (including opponents) returns to life at 1 HP immediately.

6th Circle – Midnight ShroudSU: As a standard action you may create a spread of radius 30 ft centred within your [Close] range. The spread is complete darkness, but your allies can see through it as if it were illuminated. Any opponent targeting an ally within the spread with an offensive action must make a Will save (DC = 10 + ½ your level + your KDM), or the action is wasted. A creature need only make one successful save against this effect each [Encounter], after which it is unaffected.

7th Circle – New DawnSU: You may cast greater invisibility at will as part of a swift action. This counts as a 7th Circle spell for all purposes.

2.4 Ranger

2.4.1 Determinator

Special: You may take this track in place of Battle’s Tempering in the Ranger class

You’ve lived a long life out in the wastelands, far away from friendship, safety, or even basic comfort. This has taught you to never give up, and always keep pushing through all adversity. Actually, you just get even more determined when the chips are down, and your pure grit can even disrupt magic.

1st Circle – So Far Away, We Wait For the DayEX: You start each [Encounter] with [Fast healing] 1. Whenever you take an instance of damage greater than or equal to six times the [Fast healing] you have from this ability, double it (from this ability, ignore any other stacking [Fast healing] when doubling).

2nd Circle – For the Lights Are So Wasted and GoneEX: Whenever you fail a saving throw, gain hit points equal to your current [Fast healing] from this track, and end a single magical effect within [Melee] range of circle equal to or less than the number of circles you have in Determinator.

3rd Circle – The Times Are Tough, All RightEX: When you are hit by an attack where the attack roll was 5 or more higher than your AC, heal hit points equal to twice your current [Fast healing] from this track.

4th Circle – Through the Fire and FlamesEX: You gain [Resistance] to energy damage. When you enter a space in a spread which would normally cause a negative effect when you enter the space, you ignore it (you are still affected by any effects which trigger when you start or end your turn in a spread).

5th Circle – Feel the Pain of a LifetimeEX: When you go below 0 hit points, you may instead set your hit points to be equal to 1 + your current [Fast healing] from this track. When you do this, you take [HP reduction] equal to twice your new current hit points. This [HP reduction] lasts until the end of the [Scene], and can stack up to 1 less than your maximum hit points. You cannot use this ability if it would set your hit points higher than your current maximum hit points.

6th Circle – Lost in a Thousand DaysEX: At the end of your turn, you may make a Fortitude save with DC equal to the highest save DC of any negative effect affecting you, +1 for each additional negative effect affecting you. If it succeeds, you end all negative effects currently affecting you.

7th Circle – In the Flames of Death’s Eternal ReignEX: Once per [Encounter] per ally, when an ally goes below 0 hit points you may instead set their hit points to be equal to 1 + your current [Fast healing] from this track, and then you take [HP reduction] equal to twice your ally’s new current hit points which lasts until the end of the [Scene] and stacks with [HP reduction] from Feel the Pain of a Lifetime.

2.4.2 Rappel

Special: You may take this track in place of Professional Soldier in the Ranger class

Whether it be with rappelling hooks, clawshots, simple robes, semi-organic spider webs, grapple beams or gravity magic, there is a long tradition of warriors who swing around a battlefield, using their implements to attack at range and disrupt their opponents’ weaponry and stance.

1st Circle – End of Your RopeEX: With a swift action, you may attach your melee weapons to your ropes, employ gravity magic to project them outwards, or by some other fashion throw them out to range. All your attacks with [Melee] weapons may be made out to [Close] range until the end of your turn, but still provoke attacks of opportunity if made at range, as with normal ranged attacks. When you gain your 4th circle in Rappel, you may make these attacks out to [Medium] range.

Also, your first attack each [Round] may be a Disarm or Trip attack, even when you get additional attacks after the first. The DC for saves against your Disarm and Trip combat manoeuvres is 11 + ½ your level + your KOM, this DC increases by 1 when you gain your 4th circle in Rappel, and again at 6th circle.

Also, you may Climb at your full speed up any surface without a successful Athletics check.

2nd Circle – Everyone Deserves the Chance to FlyEX: As a swift or part of a move action when there is a high surface to swing from, or a [Flying] enemy, in [Close] range, you may gain the Fly movement mode until the start of your next turn. If you do this with a [Flying] enemy, they take damage equal to your KOM.

Also, once per [Round] you may cause an attack to grapple an opponent towards you, on a hit that opponent falls [Prone] and with a swift action or part of a move action is pulled towards you 10 ft + 5 ft per 4 levels you have. A successful Reflex save (DC 10+ ½ your level + your KOM) negates the [Prone] condition and also prevents the pull.

3rd Circle – Defying GravityEX: You now do not use an action to gain the Fly movement mode from a high surface, but you can still only do it once per [Round].

When you pull an enemy towards you, you may instead move them in any direction. If they hit a surface or another creature, any creatures in the collision take damage equal to your level, and any creature hit must make a Reflex save (DC 10 + ½ your level + your KOM) or fall [Prone].

4th Circle – Underoos!EX: Thrice per [Scene], as a standard action you may immobilise an enemy in [Medium] range by rapping them in your ropes, webs, or strands of magic you use in battle. That creature must make a Reflex save (DC 10 + ½ your level + your KOM) or be [Paralysed] until the end of the [Encounter]. A creature [Paralysed] this way makes a Reflex save at the end of its turn instead of a Fortitude save to escape the paralysis, but may also choose to make a Larceny check (of the same DC) instead.

5th Circle – Great ResponsibilityEX: You may take an additional swift or immediate action per [Round].

Also, when an opponent fails a save against your Trip or Disarm combat manoeuvre, or against falling [Prone] and being pulled by you, you may replace your next attack in the attack action with a Disarm or Trip combat manoeuvre, or with the knock [Prone] and pulling attack.

6th Circle – Hook, Line and SinkerEX: When you throw an opponent into another, instead of both taking damage equal to your level, you may choose to have them both take damage as if hit by an attack with the other’s currently equipped weapon. No additional effect from an attack applies in this case, but any damage bonuses to an attack do apply.

7th Circle – They’ll Never Bring Us DownEX: Once per [Round], when throwing an opponent into another and having them take damage as if attacked, you may have one take damage as if hit by a critical hit by the other.

2.4.3 Wrangler

Special: You may take this track in place of Professional Soldier in the Ranger class

Out in the warm plains between Muercia and Roun; over the dry grasslands of the southern Karling lands; in the praire frontiers of Lorado… These are places where there are more wild animals than men. Places where lone riders can make a living herdin’ beasts of burden. And when a cowperson comes back to civilization, they remember the tricks of the trade. And darn tootin’ can they use ’em.

Many abilities from the Wrangler track use Grit. You start each [Scene] with six points of Grit per circle you have in Wrangler, and refresh at the end of a [Scene]. The GM can award you Grit for especially sharp-shootin’ feats and actions, or take Grit away if you make decisions expected of some sorta grass-bellied greenhorn son of a gun.

1st Circle – LassoEX: As a standard action, make a ranged attack out to [Close] range. On a hit, instead of dealing damage the target is tethered to you. Until the tether is cut, neither you nor the target can move past your [Close] range of the other (if they move past the range via [Teleport] or [Warp], the tether is cut). You can cut the tether on your turn as a free action, and if the target hits you with an attack, they can forgo damage to instead cut the tether.

When a tethered creature deals damage to you, you can spend any amount of Grit to reduce the damage by an amount equal to your level plus your KDM for each point of Grit spent. You can also spend Grit this way to prevent the tether being cut, if you would reduce the damage done by an attack to 0 this way.

2nd Circle – CowboyEX: At the start of an [Encounter], you may ask a question about each non-[Humanoid] or [Monstrous humanoid] opponent, as if you had made a successful Knowledge check for them.

As a free action on your turn, you may spend a point of Grit to tie off a lasso and reduce the range of a tether you have active to the current distance between you and the target.

3rd Circle – RodeoEX: If you are within [Melee] range of a larger creature and simultaneously at the maximum range of your tether with it (i.e. the tether is shorter than your [Melee] range), you may begin to Rodeo it.

When using Rodeo, you occupy the same space as the tethered creature. If you have hit that creature with an attack this turn, you may make it move up to its speed (carrying you along with it) with a move action. You may spend additional attacks in your attack action, along with a point of Grit per attack, to force the tethered creature to make attacks with its currently wielded weapons against creatures in its range.

4th Circle – HerderEX: As a standard action, or as part of a standard action where the other part is to use Lasso, create a 40 ft radius spread within [Medium] range. You may spend up to three Grit when doing this to reduce the radius by 10 per Grit spent. Creatures within the spread must make a Fortitude save (DC = 10 + 1/2 your level + your KDM) to move through the edge of the spread. Any remaining movement on a failed save is wasted.

5th Circle – Greater LassoEX: Creatures tethered to you may not [Teleport] or [Warp], and have a penalty to damage against creatures that aren’t you equal to your KDM.

6th Circle – True GritEX: When you make an attack action, you may spend up to three points of Grit to increase the range on which you threaten a critical hit to the next highest number available. When you are hit by a critical hit, as an immediate action you may spend two points of Grit to cancel all effects of the critical hit.

7th Circle – The Herd Herds ItselfEX: When you hit with a Lasso attack while already tethered to a creature, you may have the two creatures become tethered to each other. The creatures can break the tether as normal, but if they do so they also deal damage as normal to the other creature.

2.5 Rogue

2.5.1 Great Fortitude

Special: You may take this track as the Rogue’s Defensive Style, your KDM becomes Con.

Some creatures simply don’t care whether they were hit, they don’t need armor when their amazing constitution means they never feel the pain anyway.

1st Circle – Just That HardEX: Once per [Round] per circle you possess from this track, when an opponent who is not [Concealed] or [Fully concealed] makes an attack against you, if you are not [Entangled], you may make a Fortitude save and use the result in place of your AC against that attack if the result is higher than your AC.

2nd Circle – Shrug it OffEX: Once per [Encounter], if you make a successful Fortitude saving throw against an offensive action that normally deals half damage on a successful save, you may instead take no damage. Additionally, you gain a bonus to Fortitude saves equal to 1/4 your level (minimum 1).

3rd Circle – Implacable ManEX: You have immunity to [Death] effects and [Energy drained].

4th Circle – All the Force of a Great TyphoonEX: You have [Lesser resistance] to all damage.

5th Circle – I’m the Juggernaut, Bitch!EX: You never provoke attacks of opportunity.

6th Circle – A Mountain that RidesEX: Once per [Encounter], any time during a [Round], you may make a Fortitude save. You may use the result of this save to replace the results of any Reflex or Will saves you make for the rest of the [Round].

7th Circle – I’ll Be BackEX: Once per [Scene], if you become [Dead] or are rendered [Unconscious], you are revived with full hit points one [Round] after your death or knockout. You can choose not to return.

2.5.2 Mind Over Matter

Special: You may take this track as the Rogue’s Defensive Style, your KDM becomes Cha.

Acrobatic Adepts are able to dodge attacks with just their speed. Some creatures, though, can simply ignore attacks using their force of mental will, or perhaps by exerting their psychic powers over reality so that the attack never did hit.

1st Circle – Don’t Feel, ThinkSU: Once per [Round] per circle you possess from this track, when an opponent who is not [Concealed] or [Fully concealed] makes an attack against you, if you are not [Entangled], you may make a Will save and use the result in place of your AC against that attack if the result is higher than your AC.

2nd Circle – Wax OnSU: Once per [Encounter], if you make a successful Will saving throw against an offensive action that normally deals half damage on a successful save, you may instead take no damage. Additionally, you gain a bonus to Will saves equal to 1/4 your level (minimum 1).

3rd Circle – Wax OffSU: You gain the Fly movement mode and permanent Arcane Sight, as the spell.

4th Circle – Tranquil as the ForestSU: You have immunity to effects with the [Mind-affecting] descriptor and the in-combat use of the Intimidate skill.

5th Circle – Find Your CentreSU: All your movement is now a [Warp].

6th Circle – As I ThinkSU: Once per [Encounter], any time during a [Round], you may make a Will save. You may use the result of this save to replace the results of any Fortitude or Reflex saves you make for the rest of the [Round].

7th Circle – So I BecomeSU: Whenever you use Don’t Feel, Think and your opponent’s attack roll misses, that enemy becomes [Confused] until the end of their next turn.

2.5.3 Mastermind

Masterminds are experts in reading situations, the mannerisms of people, and finding tactical opportunities on the battlefield. Using their incredible perception, they can aid their allies by identifying things no-one else would notice.

Special: You may take this track as the Rogue’s Offensive Style, your KOM becomes Int or Wis.

1st Circle – Private EyeEX: You may make a Perception check and use its result any time you would make a Knowledge skill check. You use your KOM instead of your Wis modifier to calculate your Perception check bonus (if your KOM is not your Wis modifier).

2nd Circle – Sherlock ScanEX: As a move action, make a Perception check. You can identify a number of Scanned spaces within [Long] range equal to the result of the check divided by four. These spaces are those where you have detected some tactical advantage, so they can be determined by the DM if they deem that appropriate. Scanned spaces last for a [Scene], but if you use the ability again you replace the old Scanned spaces.

You gain a +4 bonus to attack rolls when you or your target are in a Scanned space. As a standard action or in place of an attack in an attack action, you may grant an ally in [Long] range this bonus while those spaces are still Scanned. This bonus does not stack with any fury bonuses.

3rd Circle – MindfulnessEX: When you make an attack roll where you or your target are in a Scanned space, or when an ally affected by your 2nd Circle ability does so, the attack deals bonus [Precision] damage equal to 1d6 times the number of circles you have in Mastermind.

4th Circle – Keikaku DooriEX: As a move action, name a number of abilities equal to the number of circles you have in Mastermind. Until the start of your next turn, whenever an opponent uses one of those abilities, either targeting you or with you in the area of effect, you gain a +4 bonus to AC and saving throws until the end of your next turn.

5th Circle – ElementaryEX: You are permanently affected as if by the true seeing spell.

6th Circle – Galaxy BrainEX: When making a Perception check, whenever you roll lower than an 8 on the d20, you may treat the result as an 8.

7th Circle – Thirty-five Minutes AgoEX: Whenever you gain a bonus from your 4th Circle while either you or the opponent using the ability is on a Scanned space, you may choose another creature in that ability’s range. If the attack roll misses you, or you save against an affect of the ability, the ability also affects that creature.

2.5.4 Spellthief

Special: You may take this track as the Rogue’s Offensive Style, your KOM becomes Int.

Many thieves steal magic artifacts, many use magical items and perhaps even a few spells to augment their roguish tricks. A rare few can steal magic itself. Spellthieves specialise in Sombramacy – shadow magic, creating fake weapons out of shadow, and even illusionary copies of themselves. They are most well known for their ability to channel magical energy directly from an unaware target, stealing a spell to use as their own.

1st Circle – Unlimited Blade WorksSLA: As a free action, you may create illusory weapons out of shadow. When you do this, you are equipped with an [Arcane] melee weapon with three properties of your choice. Due to its illusionary nature, creatures may replace their AC with the result of a Will save against attacks with this weapon. You may dispel all your illusory weapons as a free action and may only have a number created at one time equal to your Int modifier.

Also, when you gain a new circle in Spellthief (including this one), choose one spell from the Tactician or Sorcerer spell list of equal or lower circle. You gain the ability to cast this spell. You have two spell slots per circle by default, and gain any bonus spell slots from a high Int modifier as a normal spellcaster.

2nd Circle – Spell StealSU: Once per [Round] per target, when you make a melee attack that hits a [Flat-footed], [Helpless], [Confused], [Dazed], [Entangled], [Exhausted], [Stunned], [Shaken], [Frightened], [Cowering] or [Panicked] target, you may use Spell Steal. Choose one spell, spell-like or supernatural ability the target can use (you cannot choose an ability with limited uses that have been used up), and you Steal that ability. If it is an ability with unlimited uses, you steal it automatically, to steal a spell you must make a Larceny check DC=10 + 1/2 the target’s level + the target’s SAM + the spell’s circle; to steal an ability with limited uses per [Encounter] you must make a Larceny check of DC 10 + ½ the target’s level + the target’s KDM + (5-remaining uses per [Encounter] of the ability); to steal an ability with limited uses per [Scene] you must make a Larceny check of DC 13 + ½ the target’s level + the target’s KDM + (5-remaining uses per [Scene] of the ability). If you successfully Steal the ability, the target is unable to use it while you have it stored, a Will save of DC 10 + ½ your level + your Int modifier negates this effect.

When you Steal an ability, you may store it for a number of [Rounds] equal to the number of circles you possess in Spellthief. Once per [Scene] per circle you possess in Spellthief, you can make an Arcana check of DC 10 + ½ the target’s level + the target’s KDM to be able to store an ability you have in storage for the remainder of the [Scene], but the target can then make an additional Will save to regain use of the ability. You can cast any spell or use any ability you have in storage, with any TAM, SAM, KOM, KDM or ability modifier used in the ability replaced by your Int modifier. When you use the ability, it then leaves your storage.

3rd Circle – Man in the MirrorSLA: As a standard action, you may create an illusory copy of yourself out of shadow. The copy appears in an adjacent space to you and appears exactly like you, except with a few shadowy ripples which can be noticed by a Perception check of DC 10 + ½ your level + your Int modifier or by any creature with Awareness that beats that DC. The copy has all of your statistics, and you can control it by spending an action of any type to cause it to make that action (so as a move action you can make the copy make a move action of your choice), but its attacks deal no damage (any melee or raged attacks always appear to miss), any other abilities have no effect (they are felt like a save was made against them) and it has an additional 20% [Miss chance]. If the copy is hit by any attack, or fails a save against any ability, it is immediately destroyed. You can see, hear and otherwise sense anything your copy can as long as you maintain line of effect to the copy. You may only have one illusory copy active at a time and can dismiss them as a swift action.

4th Circle – A Beautiful DeathSLA: When one of your copies is destroyed, as an immediate action, you may cause it to appear as though it realistically died from the effect. This does not fool any creature who had a high enough Perception or Awareness to recognise it as a shadow copy, but is sufficient to fool any other creature that it has actually been killed.

5th Circle – Shadow CabinetSU: You gain the ability to blend in to shadow completely and move between them. There is shadow in any space not covered by a [Light] effect and adjacent to a [Small] or [Average] sized creature or object (you can manipulate the shadows so they are in any direction from the object) and in any space within two of a [Large] creature or object (shadow size of larger objects is determined by the GM). While standing in a Shadow, you are [Invisible], and are even partially absorbed into the shadow, gaining 20% [Miss chance] even against creatures who ignore the [Invisibility]. During a movement action, you can [Warp] to any shadow within your movement range.

6th Circle – Double Your FunSLA: Your illusory copy’s attacks deal damage and any abilities it uses have a normal effect. However, any damage it does is treated as if the opponent has [Greater resistance] to that damage type, any saves to reduce the effect of an ability instead negate it, and the duration of any conditions caused is halved (though to no less than one [Round], for halving purposes an [Encounter] if halved to five [Rounds] and a [Scene] halved to [Encounter]).

7th Circle – Thief of TimeSU: Once per [Scene], when you could steal a spell, instead cause the target to become [Dazed] for one round and take an extra turn on the target’s initiative count. A successful Will save of DC 10 + ½ your level + your Int modifier negates this effect.

2.5.5 Thief

Special: You may take this track as the Rogue’s Offensive Style, your KOM becomes Dex.

All Rogues are skilled in the art of theft, but only the most skilled use it in combat. With nimble fingers and quicker feet, they steal things from their opponents even in the midst of battle. So great is their skill that Thieves can even steal intangible things like magical auras from their foes.

1st Circle – StealEX: As a standard action, roll a Larceny check and target an adjacent opponent. If your Larceny check exceeds their Awareness score, you deal physical damage to that opponent equal to 1d4 per circle of Thief you have, and may steal one thing from them.

You may always steal any unwielded weapon or unequipped magical item the target holds, and may immediately start wielding a stolen weapon. If you beat their Awareness by 5 or more, you may steal their wielded weapon (as long as it is not a natural weapon). If you beat their Awareness by three times the circle of a temporary effect on the target, you may steal that effect (the effect ends when it would normally end).

2nd Circle – Steal BreathSU: As an immediate action when you deal damage with Steal, you may heal hit points equal to the damage dealt.

3rd Circle – Item ExpertiseEX: When you use items and consumables which deal damage, you count as three levels higher and your KOM counts as one higher. Each Scene, you gain one each of the following consumables, the DCs for saves against which are 10 + 1/2 your level + your Int modifier:

  • Bomb Fragment: Deal energy damage with the [Fire] descriptor to all creatures in a 30 ft radius within [Medium] range equal to 1d6 times your level plus your KOM. A Reflex save halves the damage.
  • Blizzard Mote: Deal energy damage with the [Cold] descriptor to all creatures in a wedge out to 60 ft equal to five times your KOM. A Fortitude save halves the damage.
  • Ball Lightning: Deal energy damage with the [Electricity] descriptor to all creatures in a 5 ft wide line out to your [Medium] range equal to 2d4 times your level. A Reflex save halves the damage.
  • Beaker of Acid: Deal energy damage with the [Acid] descriptor to all creatures in a 5 ft radius in [Close] range equal to 1d10 times your level plus your KOM. A Fortitude save halves the damage.
  • Blast Cone: Deal physical damage equal to three times the total of your level and KOM to up to three target creatures in [Close] range. A Reflex save halves the damage.

4th Circle – Bypass SecuritySU: When you steal something, you may steal the target’s saves. If you do, for the next two [Rounds] you gain a bonus to all saving throws and they take a penalty equal to -1 for every 4 points you beat their Awareness score by.

5th Circle – Godspeed StrikeEX: Once per [Encounter] make a melee attack against a creature in [Close] range. On a hit, instead of your normal damage you deal 2d4 per your level. At the end of the target’s next turn, they take 2d4 per your level damage again, even if the attack missed.

6th Circle – Steal BeingSU: When you steal something, you may make the target [Ethereal] until the end of your next turn. [Ethereal] creatures lose line of sight and effect to all other creatures.

7th Circle – Aeber’s ReckoningEX: Three times per [Scene] when you successfully steal something, deal additional physical damage equal to your Speed.

2.6 Sage

2.6.1 Pestilence

Special: You may take this track in place of Arcane Secrets in the Sage class.

You are a master of poison, using various Venoms to debilitate your opponents, and even spreading powerful Diseases to infect them. Choose physical, energy or magic damage when you gain this track. Your Venoms activate when you deal that sort of damage, as you either poison your weapons, or weave toxic energy into your spells.

At the start of each [Scene], choose up to four Venoms in the circles you have in Pestilence you have those Venoms prepared. You can change your active Venom with a move action to any Venom you have prepared. The first time each [Round] you deal damage of your chosen type, your target gains a stack of your currently active Venom, and each Venom inflicts different effects depending on how many stacks the target has. When it gains a stack, a creature with Venom stacks may make a Fortitude save of DC 10 + ½ your level + your KOM to lose all stack of that Venom. The effects of all Venoms expire at the end of an [Encounter]. They are all [Poison] effects.

As a standard action, you may infect a creature in [Close] range with a Disease (this is a supernatural ability). On a failed Fortitude save (DC 10 + ½ your level + your KOM), that creature becomes infected and suffers the negative effects of the Disease. Until the end of the [Encounter], any creature (except you) that ends its turn in [Melee] range of the infected creature must also make the save or be infected by the Disease. This Disease lasts until the end of the [Scene], when the infected creature must make another Fortitude save with a +5 bonus, on a successful save the Disease ends, on a failed save, it lasts until the end of the next [Scene], where another save with a +10 bonus is made, on success the Disease ends, on failure the Disease lasts for the next [Scene], with a +15 bonus at the end of that one, and so on. You may freely cure any Disease which originated from you casting it (e.g., if an ally was infected by a creature you infected) with a move action when you are in [Close] range of the afflicted creature.

1st Circle – Down with the SicknessSU: You gain the Lasting Toxin, Clot Toxin and Optical Toxin Venoms and the Fatigue Fever Disease.

  • Lasting Toxin: A creature with 1 charge of Lasting Toxin takes 1d4 damage at the start of their turn for each consecutive [Round] they have had charges of Lasting Toxin, this increases to 1d6 at 2 charges, 1d8 at 3 charges, and so on.

  • Clot Toxin: Whenever a creature with charges of Clot Toxin takes physical damage, they also take [HP reduction] equal to your KOM for each charge of Clot Toxin they have, up to a maximum half the damage that was done.

  • Optical Toxin: A creature with 1 charge of Optical Toxin is [Dazzled], a creature with 3 or more charges is [Blinded].

  • Fatigue Fever: A creature with Fatigue Fever is [Fatigued], if they ever take a swift, move and standard action in a turn, they are [Exhausted] until the end of the [Encounter].

2nd Circle – Poison ParadigmSU: You gain the Necrosis and Weakness Venoms and the Leprosy Disease.

  • Necrosis: Whenever a creature with charges of Necrosis is healed, the healing is reduced by twice your level for each charge of Necrosis it has.

  • Weakness: DCs for saves against the abilities of a creature with charges of Weakness are reduced by twice the number of charges of Weakness it has.

  • Leprosy: Whenever a creature with Leprosy takes damage they take [HP reduction] equal to the number of circles of Pestilence you have.

3rd Circle – Plague IncSU: You gain the Ice Blood and Debilitate Venoms and the Plague Disease.

  • Ice Blood: A creature with 2 charges of Ice Blood is [Slowed], and with 5+ charges, it is [Paralysed].

  • Debilitate: Choose an ability score (Str, Dex, etc.) when switching to Debilitate. A creature with charges of Debilitate has that score reduced by twice the number of charges it has.

  • Plague: When you use Plague, choose an ability score. Creatures with Plague have that ability score reduced by 4.

4th Circle – Dude, That Was Sick!SU: You gain the Adrenal Toxin, Mind Fog and Softskin Venoms and the Mummy Rot Disease.

  • Adrenal Toxin: A creature gains 2 points of Fear severity for every charge of Adrenal Toxin it has.

  • Mind Fog: A creature with 1 charge of Mind Fog is [Confused], but rolls twice and chooses their result. A creature with 2 charges is [Confused] but can reroll if they do not get Act Normally (they must take the second result). A creature with 3+ charges is [Confused].

  • Softskin: When switching to Softskin, choose physical, magical or energy damage. A creature with 2 of Softskin has [Vulnerability] to the chosen energy type, a creature with 4 charges has [Vulnerability] to all damage.

  • Mummy Rot: At the start of each of its turns, a creature with Mummy Rot takes damage equal to twice your KOM. If a creature dies while they have Mummy Rot, their corpse dissolves and they cannot be brought back to life by the Medicine skill.

5th Circle – Black DeathSU: You gain the Orbital Toxin and Containment Venoms, and the Phyresis Disease.

  • Orbital Toxin: Creatures with charges of Orbital Toxin have their [Miss chance] on attacks increased by 25% for each charge of Orbital Toxin

  • Containment: A creature with 1 or 2 charges of Containment loses the [Fly] and [Swim] movement modes if it has them, with 3 charges they also lose [Burrow] and the ability to [Teleport] and [Warp], with 5+ charges they cannot move.

  • Phyresis: At the start of each of its turns in combat, a creature with Phyresis must make a Will or Fort save (of their choice) of DC 10 + ½ their level + their KOM. If it fails, they must use every action on their turn to take offensive actions against the nearest creature.

6th Circle – PandemicSU: You gain the Paralegia and Creeping Stone Venoms, and the Shadow Disease.

  • Paralegia: A creature with 1 charges of Paralegia lose 1 swift action on their turn, with 2 they lose two swift actions, with 3 charges they also lose 1 move action, with 4 charges they are [Dazed].

  • Creeping Stone: A creature with charges of Creeping Stone is [Petrified], but can make the save against [Petrified] at any point in their turn instead of just at the end, as normal for Venoms. They get a +1 to the save for every number of charges below 3 they have, and -1 for each above 3 they have.

  • Shadow: The turn after it is infected, and at the start of every [Encounter], a creature with Shadow must make a Will save (equal to the DC of the Fortitude save against the Disease) or become [Ethereal] for the [Encounter]. While a creature is [Ethereal] as a result of this ability, line of sight and effect is blocked between the creature and other creatures.

7th Circle – The Second HorsemanSU: You gain the Black Widow Venom and the Shadow of Death Disease.

  • Black Widow: A creature is [Energy drained] twice the number of times equal to the number of charges of Black Widow it has.

  • Shadow of Death: At the start of each [Scene], a creature with Shadow of Death must make a Fortitude save (of DC equal to the disease) or instantly die.

2.6.2 Thu’um

Special: You may take this track in place of Sage’s Wrath in the Sage class.

Before Io split his essence into Tiamat and Bahamut (and then got Cyndor to help him reform himself) and hence split the draconic race, there were the Primal Dragons. More forces of nature than creatures, the Primal Dragons spoke with the Voice, a language which bends nature with its words. The Primal Dragons are almost all gone, but there are a scattered few which retain knowledge of the Voice.

For every circle of this Track, you choose one Shout, you can choose a Shout from a previous circle instead of one of the ones made available at that circle if you wish. Unless otherwise noted, Shouts are at-will abilities, and used as a standard action. The DC for any saves made for Shouts is 10 + ½ your level + you Cha modifier.

1st Circle – Makes Me Wanna ShoutSU: You can use the Voice to deal damage to your enemies.

  • Unrelenting Force: You attack one opponent in [Close] range with pure force. This deals 1d6 + your KOM damage with the [Force] descriptor and causes the opponent to be pushed away from you 5 ft plus an additional 5 ft per circle of you possess of this track. When you reach 4th circle in this track, the damage increases to 3d6 + KOM and the target is also [Battered] for two rounds. When you reach 6th circle in this track, you affect a wedge out to your [Close] range and the damage increases to 5d6 + KOM. A successful Fortitude save halves the damage and prevents being pushed back and [Battered].
  • Fire Breath: You deal 1d6 energy damage with the [Fire] descriptor per character level to one opponent in [Close] range and they start Burning. When you reach 4th circle in this track, the it deals bonus damage equal to your level against [Burning] targets. When you reach 6th circle in this track, the [Burning] you cause does not run out naturally, and you deal further bonus damage equal to your level against [Burning] targets. A successful Reflex save halves damage and prevents Burning.
  • Frost Breath: You deal 1d6 energy damage with the [Cold] descriptor per character level to one opponent in [Close] range. When you reach 4th circle in this track, you also cause the target to be [Slowed] for one [Round]. When you reach 6th circle in this track, the duration of [Slowed] increases to two [Rounds]. A successful Fortitude save halves damage and prevents [Slowed]

2nd Circle – May the Fus Be With YouSU: Your Voice manipulates the wind, to move you around at great speed or subvert your enemies.

  • Whirlwind Sprint: As a move action, you [Teleport] to an unoccupied space within 20 ft + 5 ft per circle of this track you possess. When you reach 4th circle in this track, twice per [Encounter] you may deal damage equal to your level + KOM to one opponent in a line from the start to the end of your [Teleport]. When you reach 7th circle in this track, it becomes a [Warp], and the damage is dealt to every opponent in the line.
  • Disarm: As a move action, you may cause one opponent in [Close] range to become [Flat-footed] and make a Reflex save or become Disarmed, as the combat manoeuvre. When you reach 4th circle in this track, you can target up to three opponents in [Close] range. When you reach 7th circle in this track, you can target up to three opponents in [Medium] range.

3rd Circle – ShoutcasterSU: Your Voice can either grant speed to you and your allies, or create and deteriorate armour.
