If a [Detained] creature cannot possibly attack or target you, they can act normally. Each time you cause an opponent to be [Detained] in a row, the duration increases by one round. A successful Will save (DC 10 + ½ your character level + your KOM) negates [Detained]. If a creature is [Detained] by more than one creature, it can target either of two creatures it is [Detained] by. If you die, all creatures you have [Detained] are no longer [Detained].

Also, whenever you hit a creature with an attack you deal bonus damage with the [Precision] descriptor based on how much damage and [HP reduction] you have taken in the last [Round]. These do not stack:

  • ≥ 1: 1d4 per circle you possess in this track
  • ≥ 5 times the number of circles you possess in this track: 1d6 per circle you possess in this track
  • ≥ 10 times the number of circles you possess in this track: 1d8 per circle you possess in this track

2nd Circle – Sight UnseenSU: Once per [Round], as part of a move action, the next time you hit a creature with an attack this [Round], they are [Blinded] for one [Round]. A successful Reflex save (DC=10 + ½ your level + your KOM) negates this effect.

3rd Circle – Pain, Speak to MeSU: When you use a swift action to cause [Detained] it now lasts for two [Rounds] and you can target up to two creatures in [Close] range.

Also, you gain the following bonuses to attack based on the damage and [HP reduction] you have taken in the last [Round]. These bonuses are cumulative.

  • ≥ 1: +2 to attack rolls
  • ≥ 5 times the number of circles you possess in this track: Your first attack that hits each [Round] inflicts [HP reduction] equal to the damage dealt, up to your character level, in addition to the normal damage it deals. [HP reduction] from this effect occurs after damage has been dealt.
  • ≥ 10 times the number of circles you possess in this track: Your second attack that hits each [Round] inflicts [HP reduction] equal to the damage dealt, up to your character level, in addition to the normal damage it deals. [HP reduction] from this effect occurs after damage has been dealt.

4th Circle – The Shield That Guards the Realms of MenSU: A number of times per [Round] equal to the number of circles you possess in Black Knight, when a creature within [Close] range hits you with an attack, you may choose to have that creature take damage equal to your Key Offensive Modifier. This damage ignores [Damage reduction] and all forms of [Resistance].

5th Circle – ’Tis But a Flesh Wound!SU: You may now cause [Detained] as part of a swift action.

At the start of your turn, you gain temporary HP based on the amount of damage and [HP reduction] you have taken in the last [Round]. These temporary HP stack up to half your maximum HP.

  • ≥ 1: 5 temporary HP
  • ≥ 5 times the number of circles you possess in this track: An amount of temporary HP equal to twice your KOM
  • ≥ 10 times the number of circles you possess in this track: You gain temporary HP equal to your KOM whenever you hit with an attack.

6th Circle – The Watcher on the WallSU: You gain [Lesser resistance] to all damage. Once per [Encounter], as a standard action you may make one attack. If this attack hits, you may reduce all uses of that creature’s abilities with limited uses per [Encounter] or [Scene] by 1. In addition, that creature is [Exhausted] and [Energy drained]. A successful Fortitude save (DC 10 + ½ your level + your Key Offensive Modifier) prevents the reduction of ability uses.

7th Circle – You Cannot Pass!SU: When you cause [Detained], you may now target up to three creatures in [Close] range. Also when you hit a creature for the first time in a [Round], that creature is [Energy drained], even if that creature has [Immunity] to [Energy Drained].

5.9 Brewmaster

Special: You may switch one of your Tracks for Brewmaster without using your Multiclass if you have the Livers Need Not Apply feat.

Alcohol is an integral part of most cultures on the Material Plane. It is potable, preservable and most importantly recreational. Those who have truly mastered the arts of alcohol can imbue it into their very soul, using it to heal themselves and others and wielding various odd manoeuvres in combat.

The combat manoeuvres you gain from Brewmaster count as manoeuvres for all effects that change the damage they deal and their DCs, but no ability that allows you to replace an attack with a manoeuvre may apply to them. They are always standard actions.

1st Circle – The Cause Of, and Solution To, All Of Life’s ProblemsEX: You gain the Livers Need Not Apply feat. If you already had it, or otherwise when you reach level 5, you gain the Seven Drunken Immortals feat.

2nd Circle – HangoverEX: The first time each opponent is hit by one of your melee attacks each [Round], they must make a Fortitude save with DC equal to 10 + 1/2 your level + your Con modifier. On a failed save, they become [Tipsy] for two [Rounds]. A [Tipsy] creature is [Slowed] on their next turn if they use a standard, swift and move action on their turn.

3rd Circle – Drunken MasterEX: You can use the following two combat manoeuvres:

  • Barrel Throw: As a standard action, throw a barrel of especially strong alcohol out to a space in [Close] range and choose how well aged it is as a value from 1 to 3.
    • On a 1, it instantly explodes and deals damage equal to your level + your Con modifier to all creatures within 10 ft of it and inflicts [Tipsy] for two [Rounds] (with a Fortitude save to negate as usual).
    • On a 2, it explodes at the start of your next turn and deals damage equal to twice the total of your level and your Con modifier to all creatures within 10 ft of it an inflicts [Tipsy] for two [Rounds] (with no Fortitude save).
    • On a 3, it explodes at the start of your the turn after your next and deals damage equal to five times the total of your level and your Con modifier to all creatures within 10 ft of it an inflicts [Tipsy] for two [Rounds] (with no Fortitude save).
  • Belch: As a standard action, inflict damage equal to your Con modifier to all opponents in a 15 ft wedge originating from you. This damage bypasses all [Damage reduction] and [Resistances], and you may spend up to three drink charges from Livers Need Not Apply when you Belch to increase the damage by your Con modifier again for each charge spent. Any creature damaged must make a Fortitude save or become [Tipsy] for two [Rounds] as usual, and the DC is increased by 1 for each charge spent. While a creature is [Tipsy] due to this effect, all healing they take is reduced by an amount equal your level, to a minimum of 1.

4th Circle – Iron LiverEX: You gain a +4 item bonus to Constitution. As a move action, you may gain three charges of drinks for Livers Need Not Apply.

5th Circle – Explosive CaskEX: When you use Barrel Throw, you may choose a value of 0 to make the alcohol so volatile that it violently explodes. This deals damage equal to your Con modifier to all creatures within 10 ft of the barrel and then be [Blown away] in a direction of your choice and [Tipsy] for three [Rounds]. A Fortitude save with the same DC as the DC for [Tipsy] negates both [Blown away] and [Tipsy].

6th Circle – Stage Dive!EX: You can use the Body Slam combat manoeuvre:

  • Body Slam: As a standard action, you may move up to your speed in a straight line, ignoring attacks of opportunity, and then deal damage equal to your Con modifier and inflict [Knocked down], [Battered] and [Tipsy] (the latter two for two [Rounds]) to all creatures within your [Melee] range. Creatures may make a Fortitude save with the same DC as the usual DC for [Tipsy] to negate [Tipsy] and [Battered].

7th Circle – BAD HangoverEX: Creatures who are [Slowed] by the [Tipsy] condition which you inflict are also [Confused] for one [Round].

5.10 Cerebromancy

Cerebromancers practice mind magic, the school of Enchantment, using their powers to manipulate the thoughts and memories of others. Mind mages are natural negotiators, and are able to use their skills in social situations as well as in combat. Cerebromancy is based on augmenting social skill checks, with spells cast as a free action on the successful use of an in-combat Diplomacy, Bluff or Intimidate check.

All abilities from this track are at will unless stated otherwise. DCs for saves against abilities from this track are 10 + ½ your level + your Cha modifier. All effects from this track are [Mind-affecting]. Creatures with [Immunity] to [Mind-affecting] instead gain a +4 bonus to saves against abilities from this track. When you use the Intimidate skill against creatures immune to the in-combat use of Intimidate, the DC instead increases by 4.

1st Circle – Psycho BoostSLA: You may communicate telepathically with any creature within [Long] range, and may cast world-mind at will. You gain a +2 bonus to Diplomacy, Bluff and Intimidate checks. You also gain the following three spells:

  • Inspire: You may make a Diplomacy check against an ally which instead grants a +2 bonus to attack rolls if it is successful.
  • Warn: You may make a Bluff check against an ally which instead allows them to ignore the effects of the next in-combat interaction skill check made against them if successful.
  • Courage: You may make an Intimidate check against an ally which instead grants a +1 bonus to AC and saves if it is successful.

2nd Circle – Enhanced NegotiationSLA: You gain the following two spells:

  • Invasive Intel: On a successful Intimidate check, you may learn your target’s lowest save, any [Vulnerability] they have, and any attacks that they are particularly scared of.
  • Hypnosis: On a successful Diplomacy check, you may cause your target to be [Slowed] until you or one of your allies use an offensive action against them. A successful Will save negates the [Slowed] condition.

Also, out of combat, a number of times per [Scene] equal to your Charisma modifier you may use Suggestion. You may give a creature in [Medium] range a short instruction, and if they fail a Will save they must carry it out unless it is obviously self-destructive. If it is worded to sound like a wholly reasonable idea, the creature takes a penalty on its Will save equal to the number of circles you possess in Cerebromancy.

3rd Circle – Let Me Change Your MindSLA: You gain two of the following three spells (your choice is permanent), which you can use once per [Encounter] each.

  • Charm: On a successful Diplomacy check, you may Charm your target. The creature cannot use an offensive action against you or an ally, after the first [Round] of being charmed, when it would use an offensive action, it must make a Will save. A successful Will save allows it to use that offensive action as normal and renders the creature no longer charmed; a failed save means it cannot use an offensive action against you or your allies for one [Round]. The creature remains charmed until you or an ally use an offensive action against it.
  • Confusion: On a successful Bluff check, you may Confuse your target. The creature is [Confused] for two [Rounds]. A successful Will save halves this duration.
  • Terror: On a successful Intimidate check, you may cause your target to be [Frightened] for two [Rounds]. A successful Will save negates the [Frightened] condition.

4th Circle – Thought PoliceSLA: You gain the following two spells:

  • Erase Memory: On a successful Bluff check, you may erase part of your target’s memory temporarily. Choose one active ability that creature has, until the end of the [Encounter] they cannot use that ability. A successful Will save negates this effect.
  • Greater Hypnosis: On a successful Diplomacy check you may send your target into a deep sleep. The creature becomes [Helpless] until they take damage, gain a Condition, or another creature in [Melee] range uses a move action to shake them awake. A successful Will save negates this effect.

5th Circle – MK UltraSLA: You gain the following two spells:

  • Induce Awe: On a successful Intimidate check, you may render a creature unable to attack you for the [Encounter]. If it would take an offensive action that targets you, that action is not taken. A successful Will save allows the creature to take the action; an unsuccessful Will save renders the creature no longer affected by this spell. A creature may only be affected by this ability once per [Encounter].
  • Induce Treachery: On a successful Bluff check, you confuse your target into attacking the closest creature. On a failed Will save that creature, if possible, makes a full attack action with whatever weapons it is wielding against the nearest creature.

6th Circle – Speed of ThoughtEX: You may use your interaction skills in combat as a swift action.

7th Circle – The Tyranny of Free WillSLA: You gain two of the following three spells (your choice is permanent), which you can use once per [Encounter] each.

  • Cripple Memory: On a successful Bluff check, you may remove a large part of your target’s memory. Choose one track and one type of action, until the end of the [Encounter] your target may not use abilities from the track or make actions of that type. At the end of each of its turns, the creature may make a Will save to regain their memory.
  • Dominate Will: On a successful Diplomacy check, you may take over your target’s mind. That creature may make a Will save to resist this ability, but if it fails it is [Bound] under your control. The [Bound] creature cannot act normally, you may command it to use its move action as a free action, and to use its standard action as a swift action. If a creature provokes an attack of opportunity from your controlled creature, you may use an immediate action to force it to make the attack of opportunity, which uses your attack of opportunity for the [Round]. On its initiative count, the creature may make a Will save. If it succeeds, it is no longer [Bound]
  • Freeze Thought: On a successful Intimidate check, you may shut down your target’s mind. They start [Cowering] for two [Rounds]. A successful Will save negates this ability.

5.11 Chaos Mage

Some Mages delve into the forbidden teachings of Anarchomancy. This school of magic isn’t forbidden for its potential to be used for great evil or to drive its users to sin – though it does indeed have that potential. Rather, it is forbidden simply because it is far too volatile to use in anything resembling civilised magic. Chaos Spells, as they are known, are utterly unpredictable, a single casting can have any number of effects, and their variation only increases as the spells get more powerful. The less said about Anarchomantic rituals, the better. Nevertheless, the allure of the fun inherent in chaos is strong.

Your TAM for this track is your SAM or, if you don’t have an SAM, your Cha modifier. DCs for saves against abilities in this track are 10 + ½ your level + your Cha modifier.

1st Circle – Upset the Established OrderSLA: You learn the most basic Chaos Spell, as a standard action, flip a coin:

  • Heads: You fire a blast of pure chaotic energy and deal damage equal to 1d8 per level + your Cha modifier to one enemy in [Close] range. Choose Fort, Reflex or Will on using this ability, a save of that type halves the damage done.
  • Tails: Your attack backfires and you take damage equal to your level. When you gain your 3rd circle in Chaos mage you may use this ability as part of a standard action, when that standard action is used to cast a Chaos spell, when you reach 6th circle in Chaos Mage, you may use this ability twice with one Standard action (and a third time with part of a standard action).

Also, once per [Quest], you may reroll a dice or reflip a coin used for a Chaos Spell, you must take the new result. After expending this ability, the DM may reroll or reflip at any point until the end of the [Scene], if so, you regain your use of this ability for the [Scene].

2nd Circle – And Everyone Loses Their MindsSLA: You can use a Chaos Spell to manipulate people’s minds, as a standard action target a creature in [Close] range and roll a d4:

  • 1: You charm the creature. The creature cannot use an offensive action against you or an ally, after the first [Round] of being charmed, when it would use an offensive action, it must make a Will save (no saves are allowed for the first [Round]). A successful Will allows it to use that offensive action as normal and renders the creature no longer charmed; a failed save means it cannot use an offensive action against you or your allies for one [Round]. The creature remains charmed until you or an ally use an offensive action against it.
  • 2: While you don’t change the creature’s allegiance, you make it feel bad about fighting you. The creature takes a -2 penalty to attack rolls for the rest of the [Encounter], this does not stack with penalties applied by a Diplomacy check.
  • 3: Rather than warp the mind, you simply shake it up a bit. The creature is [Shaken] for two [Rounds].
  • 4: Your hypnotic magic backfires and you are Charmed by your target. Whenever you would use an offensive action against the Charming creature or an ally, you must make a Will save. A successful Will save allows you to use that offensive action as normal and renders you no longer charmed; a failed save means you cannot use an offensive action against the Charming creature or its allies for one [Round]. You remain charmed until the end of the [Encounter] or until the Charming creature or an ally use an offensive action against it.

Also, as part of a move action you may fire a small blast of chaos energy at an opponent in [Close] range. It deals 1d4 magical damage, but if you roll a 4 you may roll two additional d4s (and the same if you roll any 4s on those, until you have rolled no 4s).

3rd Circle – Come on Bro, I Got Tiger BloodSLA: You summon defensive wards with a Chaos Spell, target all allies in [Close] or [Medium] range and roll a d6:

  • 1: Your ‘defensive’ magic takes on a blood red hue and softens your allies’ skin, granting [Vulnerability] to all damage for one [Round].
  • 2: You attempt to grant a fiery shield, but it instead just sets people on fire, causing all affected to start [Burning]
  • 3: Your allies’ skin transmutes to gain a layer of stone, granting [Lesser resistance] to all damage. For each creature with this resistance, after it has negated an amount of damage equal to twice your level, they lose the [Lesser resistance]
  • 4: Lightning crackles around your allies, making foes wary to attack. For the rest of the [Encounter], the first time each [Round] each creature hits an affected ally, they take energy damage with the [Electricity] descriptor equal to your level.
  • 5: Your allies are protected by a purple gaze, gaining a 20% [Miss chance] for the rest of the [Encounter].
  • 6: Your allies gain a translucent forcefield of shifting colours, granting [Greater resistance] to all damage for two [Rounds].

Also, at the start of your turn, roll two d20s, you heal HP equal to the difference between the results. This counts as [Fast healing].

4th Circle – Where’s the Fun in Making Sense?SLA: You harness the teleportation capabilities of your new Chaos Spell. As a standard action, roll a d8:

  • 1: You teleport yourself a considerable distance into the air and take 5d6 points of falling damage.
  • 2: You teleport slightly into the ground, you cannot move until the start of your next turn when you manage to un-stick yourself.
  • 3: You switch places with target ally in [Close] range, and you then both provoke attacks of opportunity in your new spaces. If there is no ally in [Close] range, you instead teleport to target space at the edge of your [Close] range and provoke there.
  • 4: You switch the positions of two target enemies within [Medium] range.
  • 5: All enemies in [Close] range are pulled towards you up to a distance of your choice (up to a limit of your [Close] range) by weak kinetic magic. This movement provokes attacks of opportunity as normal.
  • 6: You create a vortex of teleportation magic of a 15 ft radius with centre within [Medium] range. Any creature starting their turn in or entering this vortex is [Confused] for two [Rounds] and warped to a random space on the edge of the vortex. This vortex lasts until the end of the [Encounter].
  • 7: You may create up to five 5 ft radius teleportation circles with centres in [Medium] range. Any ally standing on one of these circles may [Warp] to any space in another as an immediate action.
  • 8: You may [Warp] every creature within your [Medium] range individually to an unoccupied space of your choice within [Medium] range.

Also, at the start of each [Scene] roll d100. You gain a bonus to move speed equal to half the result, rounded down to the next multiple of 5. If the result is greater than 30, you also do not provoke attacks of opportunity by moving for the duration of the [Scene].

5th Circle – We’re All Mad HereSLA: This Chaos Spell harnesses transmutation magic in an attempt to give your allies some extra offensive punch. As a standard action target all allies in either [Close] or [Medium] range and roll a d10:

  • 1: You’re not sure how you transmuted your allies, but it’s not nice. Your targets are [Nauseated] for one [Round].
  • 2: You end up simply morphing your allies’ weapons inside them. Your targets each hit themselves with a single melee attack with either their unarmed strike, a random natural weapon, or a random melee weapon they are wielding (chosen at random), this attack automatically hits.
  • 3: You seem to have made your elemental enchantments backfire. Until the end of the [Encounter], the first time each round one of your allies hits with a melee attack, they take energy damage with the [Fire] descriptor equal to your level.
  • 4: Your allies gain some additional corrosive glands. Until the end of the [Encounter], the first time each round one of your allies hits with a melee attack, they deal bonus energy damage with the [Acid] descriptor equal to your level.
  • 5: You grant your allies keener sight or stronger muscles, and your targets gain a +3 bonus to attack rolls for two [Rounds].
  • 6: An additional arm sprouts from your allies temporarily. Your targets gain a [Bonus Attack] whenever they make an attack action in the next two [Rounds].
  • 7: You instil your allies with a burst of speed. Your targets may immediately move up to their speed, and one of your choice may make an immediate attack action.
  • 8: Dragon scales and horns sprout from your allies for a moment as they each unleash freezing breath. You deal 1d8 energy damage with the [Cold] descriptor in a wedge out to [Close] range coming from each of your targets. A Fort save halves the damage done.
  • 9: You infuse your allies with titanic strength. The first time one of your targets hits an opponent with an attack in the next [Round] that target is [Dazed] for one [Round].
  • 10: Your allies grow in size, and gain many monstrous features and appendages. Your targets all become Large if they were not already and gain a +5 bonus to attack rolls and a +10 bonus to damage rolls for the next three [Rounds].

Also, at the start of your turn, if you are affected by an effect with a duration measured in [Rounds] you may roll a d4. On a 2 or a 3 nothing happens, on a 4 the duration is reduced by one [Round] and on a 1 it is increased by one [Round].

6th Circle – Just Who the Hell do You Think We Are?SLA: You can now use your Chaos Spells as a summoning spell. As a standard action, roll a d12:

  • 1: You summon a Valkyrie from Ysgard who provides temporary aid. You my either resurrect an ally who died this [Encounter] at full HP on an unoccupied space in [Medium] range, or fully heal one ally in [Medium] range and remove all [HP reduction] from them. In either case, all enemies within 20 ft of that ally take 1d12 damage per your level.
  • 2: You summon the maddening winds of Pandaemonium. All enemies in your [Medium] range are [Confused] for the duration of the [Encounter]
  • 3: You summon a Green Slaad for a few seconds – enough time for it to unleash a storm of corrosive chaos. All enemies in a radius equal to your [Close] range centred within [Medium] range take energy damage equal to 1d10 times your level with the [Acid] descriptor, and gain [Vulnerability] to all damage for two [Rounds]. A successful Fort save halves the damage and [Vulnerability] duration
  • 4: You summon a Beholder which quickly surveys the battlefield and fires a single petrifying beam. All effects created by spells or spell-like abilities that have dura-tions and that originate from a creature or square within range or targeted a creature within [Close] range end. In addition, one creature in the range is [Petrified] until the end of the [Encounter] unless it succeeds on a Fort save.
  • 5: You summon an Illithid which controls the mind of a target creature before it phases out of the plane. You control the actions of target creature in [Close] range on its next turn unless it succeeds on a Will save. Whenever you command the creature to take an action, it may make a Will save to resist the control, using up the action’s cost without doing it.
  • 6: You summon a Riftrunner which makes a lightning run through the battlefield before teleporting away. You may create a 50 ft line originating from you, then another 50 ft line originating from the end of that one, and then two more originating from those before. You deal energy damage with the [Electricity] descriptor equal to four times your level to all creatures in those lines.
  • 7: You summon an Efreet which creates various fiery pillars which erupt across the battlefield, before it itself disappears in a torrent of flame. You create up to six 10 ft radius spreads within [Close] range, creatures in those spreads take energy damage with the [Fire] descriptor equal to 1d6 times your level, a successful Reflex save halves damage.
  • 8: You summon a Gravinid which causes a quick burst of gravity then burrows back into the ground to leave. Target creature within [Close] range is [Knocked down] and takes damage equal to twice your level.
  • 9: You summon a Coautl which looks poorly on your chaotic magic and disappears in a blinding flash of light. You are [Blinded] for one [Round].
  • 10: You summon a Hexite, which passively does nothing but drain your magic before disappearing away in a metallic green flash. You cannot use spells or spell-like abilities on until the end of your next turn.
  • 11: You summon a Marut, which is not at all happy and strikes you with its thunderous fist. You take damage equal to three times your level which is not affected by [Damage reduction] or [Resistance].
  • 12: You summon a huge and ferocious wyvern but it is unfortunately also dead and falls on you. All creatures in a 15 ft radius of you, including you, are [Knocked Down] and take physical damage equal to five times your level. The corpse stays around occupying this area and acts as an obstacle. You also drop a chip.

Also, whenever you succeed in a save against an effect, you may roll a d6. On a 6, the creature the effect originated from is targeted by the same effect and must make a save against it.

7th Circle – Some Men Just Want to Watch the World BurnSLA: You learn the final and most unpredictable Ultimate Chaos Spell. As a standard action, roll a d20:

  • 1: You explode in a climax of chaotic energy. You immediately die, and all creatures within your [Close] range take damage equal to eight times your level.
  • 2: You turn into a frog until the end of the [Encounter]. You take half your HP in [HP reduction] and cannot attack or use abilities. A successful Fortitude save ends the effect and you get a Fortitude save at the end of each of your turns.
  • 3: All the ground within a 30 ft radius of you turns into lava. Any creature [Flying] above lava takes energy damage equal to three times your level with the [Fire] descriptor at the end of their turn. Any creature that is not [Flying] that starts its turn in or enters a space with lava in it takes energy damage with the [Fire] descriptor equal to six times your level, and can only move through it as through water.
  • 4: You phase out of the Plane for a few moments, becoming [Ethereal] for two [Rounds]. While you are [Ethereal] as a result of this ability, line of sight is blocked between you and other creature, and line of effect is blocked between you and any other creature’s attack, abili¬ty, or effect.
  • 5: You glimpse echoes of the future or dark secrets no-one should learn. You become [Frightened] for one [Round].
  • 6: You accidentally utter a word of Dark Speech. All non-magic equipment on your person is shattered into dust and lost completely.
  • 7: A bucket of water is summoned from the ether and thrown in your face. You are [Revealed] for one [Round].
  • 8: You us chaotic magic to bend light around you and become [Invisible] until the end of the [Encounter].
  • 9: You reverse the polarity of gravity in the area. All [Flying] creatures in [Medium] range lose [Flying] and access to the Fly movement mode for the rest of the [Encounter], and all non-[Flying] creatures gain [Flying] and access to the Fly movement mode for the rest of the [Encounter].
  • 10: You cause a small localised blizzard to appear. You create a 15 ft radius spread within [Medium] range which deals 1d6 damage per level to all creatures within it at the end of each of your turns and lasts until the end of the [Encounter]. A successful Fortitude save halves the damage dealt.
  • 11: You tap into Sanguimancy for a moment to cause the wounds of all your enemies to become impossible to close. All enemies in [Close] range are [Battered] until the end of the [Encounter], a successful Fortitude save reduces this duration to two [Rounds].
  • 12: Time stops momentarily, but a bit more for one person. All creatures in [Medium] range may immediately move up to their speed, and one of your choice may make an immediate attack action – but they also drop a chip.
  • 13: Necromantic energies ravage one target. One creature in [Close] range takes energy damage with the [Negative] descriptor equal to six times your level and is [Battered] for two [Rounds]. A successful Will save halves damage, negates [Battered], and means the damage can’t reduce the creature below 1 HP. This is a [Death] effect.
  • 14: You grant all your allies a blessing of randomness. Each ally within [Close] range may, once during their next turn, reroll any die roll on seeing the result, they must take the new result.
  • 15: You bombard one creature with so much energy they cannot move from the chaos around them. One creature in [Close] range is [Dazed] for two [Rounds].
  • 16: You draw upon the power of chaotic dragons to turn one of your allies into one. One target ally in [Close] range gains a +7 item bonus to AC and attack rolls and may, as a standard action, deal energy damage with a descriptor of their choice equal or 1d6 times their level to all enemies in a wedge out to their [Close] range – a successful save of their choice and using the attack halves the damage done.
  • 17: You infuse an ally with enough positive energy to bring back the dead. Either resurrect any dead creature at full HP in a space adjacent to you, or heal one ally in [Medium] range to full HP, remove all conditions and all [HP reduction].
  • 18: You mimic any ability from another creature you can see. Choose one ability that you know of that a creature you have line of effect to can use, and then use that ability.
  • 19: You are infused with the power of Limbo and become completely untouchable. You gain [Immunity] to all conditions and all damage for two [Rounds].
  • 20: Roll the d20 twice, you may choose neither, either or both results of the Chaos Spell to happen.

5.12 Charioteer

Special: Goliaths may switch one of their tracks for Chef without using their multiclass. Also, you must take the Ride skill as trained if you have this Track. You obviously would, but you really need to.

In most of the Material Plane, people ride horses when they need speed or a good vantage point over the battlefield. However, in parts of the world where agriculture is sparse enough that horses cannot support the weight of a rider, chariots are still in fashion, used by groups like the Wild Elves of the Rhyllia, the Thales of Cruxis, and, thanks to their size being too much for all but the sturdiest of horses, the Goliaths of Kamigawa and Pherae.

That said, chariots do have their upside. Their size allows them to function as cover for other fighters, and their speed and noisiness makes them effective as shock troops - multiplied by the fact that multiple people can stand in a chariot and attack from the mobile platform.

1st Circle – Yoke and WheelEX: Your Personal Mount occupies a 10 ft x 15 ft area, with only the rear two spaces occupiable by you or a passenger. Between [Scene]s you can expand your Mount to add 5 ft to the long side, and two more spaces occupiable by passengers, up to a maximum of 5 ft per circle you have in Charioteer. The shorter side increases by 5 ft for every 15 ft added (so up to a maximum size of 20 ft x 50 ft).

Your Personal Mount’s Speed is equal to yours plus 20, plus an additional 5 for every 5 ft you have added to its long dimension. When moving you must keep track of which way your Mount is facing, and you must use 10 ft of movement whenever you change its direction, increasing to 20 ft if you change its direction by more than 90 degrees (i.e. 2 hexes).

Creatures riding your Personal Mount are [Covered] and have [Resistance] to all damage against attacks and effects whose line of effect goes through the front of your Mount. They are, however, [Flat-footed] against all attacks whose line of effect goes through the rear of your Mount.

2nd Circle – Dread of Their HoovesEX: The first time each [Round] each creature riding your Personal Mount hits a creature within 20 ft of your Mount with an attack, the target of the attack is [Shaken] for two [Rounds]. A Will save (DC = 10 + 1/2 your level + your KOM) negates the [Shaken] effect and a given creature can only be affected by this ability once per [Round]. The Will save is made at a -4 penalty if you used the Charge manoeuvre while riding your Mount in the last [Round].

3rd Circle – Advanced TechnologyEX: Choose two of the following bonuses to apply to your Personal Mount:

  • Light Frame: You can make a standard action to attack during a move action to move while riding your Mount.
  • Slinger Platform: Your allies who are riding your Mount as passengers gain a +3 item bonus to ranged attack rolls.
  • Scythed Wheels: The first time each [Round] that one of the two long sides of your Mount enter a space within 10 ft of each opponent, that opponent takes damage equal to your level.
  • Trampling Horses: As a standard action, you may move your Mount up to its speed forwards in a straight line, during which you can move through spaces occupied by other creatures. Whenever you move through a space occupied by another creature, you or any passengers may make a single melee attack against that creature. Each creature riding your Mount can only make one such attack during this action.
  • Side Armour: Creatures riding your Mount also gain [Covered] and [Resistance] against attacks and effects whose line of effect goes through one of the long sides of your Mount.
  • Low Berth: Passengers can mount or dismount your Mount as a free action once per [Round].

4th Circle – Din of Their WheelsEX: Dread of Their Hooves instead inflicts [Frightened]. If the target fails the Will save, you may cause all opponents within your [Close] range to make a Will save (of the same DC) or become [Shaken] for two [Rounds]. This does not stack with the fear from Dread of Their Hooves.

5th Circle – Perfected FormEX: Improve the benefits you gained from the two options you chose for Advanced Technology:

  • Light Frame: Your Mount gains a +30 bonus to Speed.
  • Slinger Platform: The item bonus to attack rolls increases to +5.
  • Scythed Wheels: Creatures damaged by the ability take a -20 penalty to Speed for one [Round] and start [Bleeding]. A Fortitude save (DC = 10 + 1/2 your level + your KOM) negates this effect, and on a success a creature can’t be affected by the reduced speed and [Bleeding] for the remainder of the [Encounter].
  • Trampling Horses: When you use the ability to trample over creatures, you may make a single melee attack against every creature whose space you move through.
  • Side Armour: The bonus you gain to AC from [Covered] when the cover is from Charioteer abilities increases to +4. You and passengers on your Mount are no longer [Flat-fooed] against attacks from behind.
  • Low Berth: Whenever your Mount moves adjacent to one of your allies, you may have them become a Passenger as a free action. An ally can dismount your Mount as a free action not on their turn as long as your Mount is moving.

6th Circle – Mounted ArtilleryEX: Choose one of the four weapons below to add to your Mount. This takes up the space of three passengers on your Mount, and each may be used as a standard action by any Passenger.

  • Edelweiss Catapult: When used, target a 20 ft radius spread centered on a space within [Long] range, which you do not need to have line of sight to. At the end of the [Round], all creatures in the radius take 2d4 physical damage per your character level and are [Blown away] from the centre of the spread. A Reflex save (DC = 10 + 1/2 your level + your KOM) halves the damage but does not negate the [Blown away]. The Catapult may be used again after it has had one full [Round] in which it was not used.
  • Ma’arim Scorpion: When used, target a 5 ft wide line out to [Long] range. All creatures not on your Personal Mount who are in the line take 1d8 physical damage per your character level which ignores all [Damage reduction] and [Resistance]. A passenger of your Personal Mount must use a move action to reload the Scorpion before it can be used again.
  • Valkoff Lance: When used, target a space within [Long] range. At the end of the [Round], all creatures not on your Personal Mount in a 5 ft line between the Lance and the target space take 1d4 magical damage per your character level. A Fortitude save (DC = 10 + 1/2 your level + your KOM) halves the damage. At the end of the next [Round] all creatures within 50 ft of the target space take 1d12 magical damage per your character level and are [Battered]. A Reflex save (DC = 10 + 1/2 your level + your KOM) halves the damage, prevents it from reducing affected creatures below 1 hit point and negates the [Battered] condition. This is a [Death] effect. The Lance may be used again after it has had one full [Round] after this explosion.
  • Lyceni Totem: When used, all allies within [Medium] range gain a +20 bonus to speed, [Immunity] to [Mind-affecting] effects, and a +3 bonus to attack rolls and Will saves for three [Rounds]. The Totem may only be used once per [Encounter].

7th Circle – Squad Seven, Move Out!EX: If all of your allies in the [Encounter] are riding your Personal Mount, you all gain a +2 bonus to all d20 rolls.

5.13 Chef

Special: Halflings may switch one of their tracks for Chef without using their multiclass.

Some people want to go on a great adventure, but aren’t suited for the battlefield. They aren’t strong, they aren’t fast, and they have no magical talent. But, one talent which is often overlooked by trail-ration-addicted adventurers is the ability to cook. Halflings especially excel at fine on-the-road cuisine, but all races with a good sense of taste and smell and a knack for finding ingredients can become valued members of a party just through their culinary prowess.

1st Circle – Yes, Chef!EX: At the start of each [Scene], with an hour of effort you may make a Meal for up to six allies (including you) which start the [Scene] in (or able to get to) your [Melee] range. A Meal consists of a Starter, a Main Course, and a Dessert, each of which consists of one different Ingredient you have access to. Your allies who receive the meal gain the effects defined by each Ingredient (for the part of the meal it is assigned to) for the duration of the [Scene].

The DM may, at their discretion, limit access to Ingredients but this should only be in circumstances of extreme poverty or austerity. Bonuses from Meals do not stack with bonuses from other Meals.

You gain access to all Apprentice level Ingredients.

2nd Circle – Eat Your VitaminsEX: You may add a Vitamin to the Starter when you make a Meal. Vitamins are special Ingredients which can only be added to the Starter with this ability (so you can only have one). The Vitamins are:

  • Protein: +2 to Strength
  • Carbos: +2 to Dexterity
  • Iron: +2 to Constitution
  • Calcium: +2 to Intelligence
  • Zinc: +2 to Wisdom
  • Carotens: +2 to Charisma

3rd Circle – Kitchen ColosseumEX: You gain access to Journeyman Ingredients and may add two Ingredients as the Main Course to a Meal.

4th Circle – Vegetarian OptionEX: You may make two Meals at a time. Each of your six allies may choose one of the two Meals to gain the benefits of (they cannot choose both).

5th Circle – Mithril ChefEX: You gain access to Master Ingredients and may add two Ingredients as the Dessert to a Meal.

6th Circle – Second BreakfastEX: At any time, even not the start of a [Scene], you may make two Meals as normal with one hour of effort. These Meals overwrite the effects of any previous Meals you have made this [Scene], and cannot affect allies who have not already benefitted from a Meal this [Scene].

7th Circle – Banquet of the GodsEX: Once per [Quest], you may make a Meal with three Ingredients and two Vitamins as the Starter, four Ingredients as the Main Course, and four Ingredients as the Dessert.

5.13.1 Ingredients

5.13.1.1 Apprentice

Bounty of the Sea

  • Main Course: You may make an Athletics check in place of the roll for an Acrobatics check.
  • Dessert: You gain the Swim movement mode.

Pain au Chocolat

  • Starter: When you are healed by any effect which isn’t [Fast healing], you heal an additional amount equal to twice the number of times you dealt damage in the last [Round]
  • Dessert: At the end of your turn, your [HP Reduction] is reduced by your level.

Iced Scream

  • Main Course: When you make a successful Intimidate check, you may deal energy damage with the [Cold] descriptor equal to your level to once target, and their penalty to AC and saves is doubled.
  • Dessert: When you are affected by a [Fear] effect, you may delay the effect (and any additions to the ‘Fear Ladder’) for one [Round].

A Stitchin Lime

  • Starter: You gain a +1 deflection bonus to AC.
  • Main Course: You cannot be targeted by attacks made by a creature that are not on their turn, except for attacks of opportunity.

Nutritionally Complete Powder

  • Main Course: When you use a swift, standard and move action in one [Round] to do things which aren’t skill checks, gain temporary hit points equal to twice your level.
  • Dessert: Your Vigour checks grant temporary hit points as if they were 5 points higher.

Confirm Tofu

  • Starter: When you roll a natural 20 on a skill check or other roll where it may not automatically succeed, your check automatically succeeds.
  • Main Course: When an opponent scores a critical hit against you they must roll another attack roll, the critical hit is only scored if that second attack roll would hit you. Your rolls of a natural 1 do not automatically miss.

Chargecuterie Board

  • Starter: You take no penalty to AC on using the Charge maneouvre. Your Charge attacks can hit [Flying] opponents even if you are not [Flying].
  • Dessert: If a Charge is not targeted at you and passes through your [Melee] range, you can end the Charge and force the attacker to attack you. They do not gain the bonuses from using the Charge manoeuvre on that attack.

Muscle Food

  • Starter: Your Power Attacks deal an additional point of damage for each two points of penalty taken to attack roll.
  • Main Course: Once per [Scene], gain a +2 bonus to the ability score you use for your KOM for the [Encounter].

Ghoulash

  • Main Course: When an opponent fails a saving throw aganst your Grapple maneouvre, you may make an immediate attack with your unarmed strike or natural weapon. This attack does damage as normal, but cannot inflict any additional effects.
  • Dessert: You gain [Immunity] to the [Sickened] and [Nauseated] condition, and cannot suffocate.

Sauvignon Mind Blank

  • Starter: You gain a +2 bonus to Will saves.
  • Dessert: You gain [Immunity] to [Charmed], and any effect which forces you to take a specific action or target (or not target) a specific creature.

Cured Pork

  • Starter: When you are healed by any effect except for [Fast healing], heal an additional amount equal to your level.
  • Main Course: When any negative effect on you expires or is removed, gain [Resistance] to all damage for one [Round] (this can stack to [Greater resistance])

5.13.1.2 Journeyman

Critical Bread Roll

  • Starter: You deal additional damage on a critical hit equal to your level.
  • Main Course: When you score a critical hit, roll an additional attack roll. If that attack roll would hit, deal the bonus damage and inflict all bonus effects you add to critical hits again.

Steamed Hams

  • Main Course: If you are [Burning], [Bleeding] or afflicted by [Frostbite], you gain 10% [Miss chance] for each [Round] you have consecutively had that condition, up to 50%.
  • Dessert: [Burning], [Bleeding] and [Frostbite] do not deal damage or [HP reduction] to you, and instead heal you for the same amount.

Eyes Cream

  • Starter: You gain a +4 bonus to Perception and Awareness, and can always see [Invisible] creatures.
  • Dessert: [Fear] effects only progress you up the ‘Fear Ladder’ by half the normal amount.

Lum Berry

  • Starter: You gain a +2 bonus to any saving throw that would prevent a negative effect or condition (so not for saves which would solely reduce damage done to you).
  • Main Course: Once per [Scene], end any condition affecting you as a free action, you can do this even if you cannot take actions.

Failafel

  • Main Course: Once per [Encounter], when you fail a save against an effect where succeeding on the save would half the damage you take, half the damage you take anyway (you are still inflicted with any additional effects or conditions)
  • Dessert: When you make a saving throw, treat any penalty you have to saving throws or any bonus the user of the ability has to DCs as a total of up to 3 points lower.

Cordon Blur

  • Main Course: You may make an Athletics check in place of any Stealth roll you make, and vice versa.
  • Dessert: Whenever you miss an attack due to [Miss chance], gain 20% [Miss chance] for one [Round], this stacks up to 60%.

Wingbearing Energy Drink

  • Starter: You gain a +15 bonus to movement speed.
  • Dessert: You gain the Fly movement mode.

Cold Cut Beef

  • Starter: Your attacks deal an additional 3 points of energy damage with the [Cold] descriptor.
  • Main Course: Opponents take a -5 penalty to speed for every 15 points of damage you dealt to them in the last [Round].

Jewellery Soup

  • Main Course: At the start of each [Encounter], you may choose any number of items you are attuned to, and lose all benefits from those items for the [Encounter]. You gain a +1 bonus to d20 rolls for each item you are not benefitting from in this way.
  • Dessert: You can attune to an additional Lesser magic item.

5.13.1.3 Master

Blood Sausage

  • Main Course: When you hit with an attack, you heal hit points equal to half the damage dealt, up to a maximum of your KOM.
  • Dessert: You gain [Immunity] to [Battered] and [Bleeding], and gain [Resistance] to any amount of [HP reduction] you take from a source which is not yourself.

Chocolate Reroll

  • Main Course: Once per [Encounter], you may reroll a d20 as a free action after seeing the result. You must keep the result of the reroll.
  • Dessert: You can reroll any d12 once after seeing the result (taking the result of the reroll) as long as it is not part of a damage roll.

Necrotic Fruits

  • Starter: Your attacks deal an additional 5 points of energy damage with the [Negative] descriptor.
  • Main Course: If multiple opponents in your [Melee] range are healed simultaneously, gain a +2 bonus to your attack and damage rolls for one [Round] for every 20 hit points healed in total simultaneously.

Robster Thermador

  • Starter: You gain a +3 bonus to Larceny, Stealth, Acrobatics and Ride.
  • Main Course: You may make a Larceny check in place of the roll for an Acrobatics, Vigour or Intimidate check.

Crystal Shrimp

  • Starter: When you deal damage, you may ignore a number of points of [Damage reduction] and [Resistance] equal to your KOM.
  • Dessert: At the start of each [Round], you may choose to change all magical damage you deal into physical damage and vice versa. When you deal energy damage, you can choose the descriptor (from [Fire], [Cold], [Acid], [Electricity] and [Negative]).

Dragon Beard Noodles

  • Starter: You gain additional maximum hit points equal to twice your level.
  • Dessert: You gain [Immunity] to [Deafened], [Blinded], [Entangled], and [Energy drained].

Unblockable Spice

  • Starter: You may make an additional immediate action each [Round], but only when it is not your turn.
  • Main Course: When a creature replaces their AC against an attack you make with any other roll or modifier, ignore all [Miss chance] and gain a +4 bonus to your attack roll.

Oni-Giri

  • Starter: The DC of saves against all of your abilities increases by 2.
  • Dessert: As a free action, you may increase your size to [Large], ignoring all penalties and gaining and additional +10 bonus to your [Melee] range.

Stun-Dried Tomatoes

  • Main Course: When an effect simultaneously inflicts a condition on two of your allies and you, you may ignore that condition (the two allies must still be inflicted with the condition, even if they also have this effect active).
  • Dessert: When you are [Stunned] or [Dazed], you may still take a swift and a move action.

5.14 Chirurgeon

The field of chirugery is a widely rebuked discipline, being a form of applied biomancy that taps on and accelerates the natural regenerative forces in a being through arcane magic. With the removal of a divine or primal influence, this unchecked regeneration can lead to wild, unpredictable mutations in the hands of the unskilled, even being encouraged by some more eccentric chirurgeons. As such, the method is widely abhorred by more traditional healers, even being outlawed and branded as heresy by more zealous factions.

1st Circle – RegenerizeSLA: As part of a move action, you may grant a stack of [Regenerize] to an ally within [Medium] range. An ally with [Regenerize] gains [Fast Healing] equal to your level plus the number of circles you possess in Chirurgeon for each stack of [Regenerize]. [Regenerize] lasts for 2 [Rounds] and expires at the end of your turn. Whenever you grant an ally a [Regenerize] effect beyond the first, the duration of any other stacks is reset. Each creature can have a maximum number of [Regenerize] stacks equal to the number of circles you possess in Chirurgeon plus one.

2nd Circle – VitalizeSLA: As a swift or immediate action, you may consume a stack of [Regenerize] on an ally within [Medium] range to give that ally one of the following bonuses that expires at the end of their turn:

  • +15ft to movement speed
  • +2 to AC
  • +2 to Attack rolls
  • +5ft to their melee range
  • +2 to any trained skill

Whenever you target an ally with your Regenerize ability, for each instance of [Regenerize] already on that target, you may heal that ally for an amount equal to your KDM

3rd Circle – ImmunateSLA: As a swift action, you may consume up to three stacks of [Regenerize] you have applied within [Medium] range on any number of allies. When you do, for each stack expended, you may remove one of the following conditions from an ally within medium range: [Bleeding], [Blinded], [Burning], [Confused], [Dazzled], [Deafened], [Exhausted], [Fatigued], [Frightened], Nauseated], [Paralyzed], [Shaken], [Sickened], [Slowed] or [Stunned].

Additionally, whenever an ally with one or more stacks of [Regenerize] is forced to make a saving throw by an enemy, you may consume one stack as an immediate action to give that ally +2 to that save until the start of their next turn.

4th Circle – CoalescenceSLA: You gain [Fast Healing] equal to your KDM for each ally with a [Regenerize] stack that you have created, with a maximum of thrice your KDM.

You may take an additional swift or immediate action per turn.

5th Circle – GalvanizeSLA: As an immediate action, you may expend 3 [Regenerize] stacks you have applied within [Medium] range on any number of allies. When you do, you may grant one ally within medium range [Temporary HP] equal to your level plus your KDM, multiplied by 3.

6th Circle – Accelerated ResynthesisSU: Any ally affected by a [Regenerize] originating from you has [Damage Reduction] equal to half your level.

You are [Immune] to the [Fatigued], [Exhausted], and [Energy Drained] conditions, and can no longer age.

7th Circle – Puppeteered BiolysisSU: Any Ally affected with [Regenerize] does not become [Disabled] or [Dying] when at 0 HP or below. Furthermore, an Ally under a [Regenerize] effect is only rendered [Dead] after starting two consecutive turns at negative hp below their CON modifier.

5.15 Chronomancy

The lost 44th Order were specialists in Chronomancy, the magic of time. While Chronomancers specialised in complex thaumaturgy, rituals involving the manipulation of the very flow of time itself, they still used basic Chronomancy as part of their Spellcasting repertoire. While the 44th Order are now wiped out due to a ritual that cost their lives, by the very nature of their magic, the basics of Chronomancy persist, appearing in mages in the present day, and even learned by some with familial ties to the lost order.

1st Circle – Cometh the HourSU: You can manipulate the temporal state of yourself and the targets of your attacks. Once per [Round], as part of a standard, swift or move action which is used to make an attack or use an offensive ability, you may use one of the following two abilities:

  • Localised Temporal Stutter: Any modifiers to attack rolls or DCs and effects of your abilities are calculated as if you were in your state one [Round] ago. Hence, all conditions and effects affecting you this turn that weren’t last turn have no effect on the roll, effects or DCs. When you gain your 4th Circle in Chronomancy, this increases to two [Rounds] ago.
  • Aggressive Temporal Stutter: One target of your attack or ability, or one creature in the area of effect of your ability, is affected by the Temporal Stutter. Target creature has all modifiers to its AC, saves, [Resistances] or [Damage reduction] calculated as they were one [Round] ago. When you gain your 4th Circle in Chronomancy, this increases to two [Rounds] ago.

2nd Circle – Wibbly-Wobbly, Timey-WimeySU: At the start of your turn, you may destroy all Echoes you have and create an Echo in the space you currently occupy. An Echo is incorporeal and invisible, though it is a magical effect detectable by arcane sight, and while it occupies a space, other creatures can occupy the space with it. When you make an attack, cast a spell, or use an ability with one of your Echoes in [Close] range, you may attack, cast or use the ability as if you were in the space of the Echo. When doing this, you determine line of sight and line of effect from the Echo, but you do not require Line of Sight or Line of Effect to the Echo.

3rd Circle – 88 MPHSLA: Once per [Encounter] each, as a standard action, you may use haste and slow, as the spells. The DC for slow is 10 + ½ your level + your Int modifier.

4th Circle – Time Marches OnSU: You gain access to the following two abilities:

  • Secondary Echo Conjuration: Once per [Round], when you move you may create an Echo at any point during your movement. You may use this Echo for Wibbly-Wobbly, Timey-Wimey.
  • Minor Temporal Rebate: Once per [Encounter], as standard action, one ally in [Close] range gains an additional use of an ability with limited uses per [Encounter], or an additional spell slot of any circle they know spells of. A creature can only be affected by one Minor Temporal Rebate per [Encounter].

5th Circle – Time is Running OutSLA: Once per [Scene], as a standard action, you may stop time in one of two ways:

  • Singular Temporal Exception: Once creature in [Close] range takes 1d4+1 extra turns, outside of the initiative order. During these turns, they lose line of effect to all creatures except themselves, and any abilities they use cannot cause damage or effects or inflict conditions on other creatures. A creature may make a DC 10 + ½ your level + your Int modifier Will save to be unaffected by this ability.
  • Localised Temporal Pause: For 1d4+1 [Rounds], the duration of all effects acting on creatures or within or on spreads within [Medium] range do not count down. For example, an effect with a one [Round] duration does not run out until the end of the Localised Temporal Pause.

6th Circle – Time to Tip the ScalesSLA: Once per [Encounter], as a standard action, you may place one creature in [Close] range into temporal stasis for two [Rounds]. The creature is incapable of acting or perceiving its surroundings, but it gains [Immunity] to dam¬age and [HP reduction], it cannot be targeted by an attack or ability, and line of effect is blocked between the creature and any attack, ability, or ef¬fect. The creature may make a Will save (DC 10 + ½ your level + your Int modifier) to negate this effect.

7th Circle – Can’t Let You Do That!SU: Once per [Encounter], as a swift action, you may revert yourself to the state you were at the start of your previous turn. This includes HP, conditions, position and all other effects. If a creature is occupying the space(s) you occupied at the start of last turn, you move to the nearest available space. This movement is a [Warp] effect.

5.16 Cyberspace Mastermind

Cyberspace Masterminds are masters of Mirror Magic, and though many fashion themselves as researchers and wielders of technology, it all comes down to their latent abilities in Spectramancy. This track allows you to use Proxies to control the battlefield and act far away from your actual position.

Proxies are not creatures and therefore may not be designated as allies or opponents.

As a standard action, you may create any number of Proxies, up to the number of circles you possess in this track, within your [Medium] range. You can create Proxies of any type you have access to, delete any number of your Proxies you control as a standard action, or convert any number of existing Proxies into a single other type of Proxy as a swift action. You may only have a number of Proxies equal to the number of circles you possess in this track active at any given time.

Proxies occupy a single space. Creatures can move into and out of space occupied by Proxies, but if a creature ends a movement in a square occupied by a Proxy, it is immediately shunted to the last unoccupied square it was in.

Whenever you move, each of your Proxies can move up to an equal number of spaces. As a free action once per [Round], you may cause any number of your Proxies to use or cease to use the Burrow, Fly or Swim movement modes so long as you possess the movement mode in question, gaining or losing relevant conditions. Proxies never provoke attacks of opportunity for these actions. Effects that would trigger as a result of movement trigger as normal but only as a result of the movement of either you or a single Proxy that you can normally act through per movement.

Proxies must maintain Line of Effect to you and remain within your [Medium] range. If a Proxy fails to satisfy both of these requirements at any time, it is immediately relocated to a square adjacent to you, of your choice. Movement and effects with the [Teleport] descriptor are exceptions in that if at the end of one of those effects the Proxy would not be within [Medium] range or Line of Effect, then the movement is simply cancelled(which may result in them appearing next to you anyway if you moved and the Proxy didn’t).

While you have at least one Proxy, your Line of Sight extends from your own space and the spaces of all your proxies. Unless otherwise specified, Proxies do not block Line of Sight or Line of Effect. Neither the Stealth skill nor the [Invisible] condition ever prevent creatures from gaining Line of Sight to your Proxies, and a Proxy’s true nature is always obvious to all observers.

Choose your Intelligence, Wisdom or Charisma modifier to be the TAM for this Track.

1st Circle – Nos, ProxyEX: You gain the ability to create Mirror and Observer proxies.

  • Mirror: The most basic type of Proxy, Mirror Proxies represent you abroad. You may take any action as if you were standing in a space occupied by one of your Mirror Proxies. Likewise, actions and effects targeting or otherwise affecting your Mirror Proxies target or affect you through the Proxy instead. However, Mirrors are extensions of a singular creature, and thus no matter how many of your Mirrors would suffer a single effect, it affects you only once. Effects that force creatures to move or prevent them from moving (including conditions like [Blown away] or [Checked]) are exceptions, and affect you and each Mirror independently. You still make a single save for yourself and all your Mirrors against such effects.
  • Observer: Useful for keeping an eye on your friends. When first created or converted, an Observer attunes to an ally within your [Medium] range. Once attuned, an Observer can freely move outside of your [Medium] range and break Line of Effect with you. Instead, it must maintain Line of Effect to the attuned ally and remain within that ally’s [Medium] range. If the Observer fails to satisfy both of these requirements at any time, it is immediately relocated to a square adjacent to that ally, of your choice. Whenever that ally moves, you can direct the Observer to move an equal number of spaces, and you can communicate with that ally through the Observer regardless of distance. Only you and the attuned ally can ever have Line of Sight to the Observer Proxy, and creatures can end their movements in the same space as an Observer Proxy without being shunted out as normal.

2nd Circle – FirewallSU: You gain the ability to create Firewall Proxies. Unlike other Proxies, Firewalls are immovable, take a standard action to convert proxies into them, and occupy a 15 ft long by 5 ft wide line. If converted from another type of Proxy, it must occupy one of the spaces the Firewall occupies. Firewalls cannot be placed in occupied spaces, and they function different from regular walls in that a Firewall blocks a square itself, and blocks passage for [Flying], [Swimming], and [Burrowing] creatures as easily as it does others. For those not standing in Firewalls they block line of effect beyond, but not inside their spaces. Allies may move through Firewalls freely, but opponents can only voluntarily move into a square occupied by one of your Firewalls if they make a successful Fortitude save (DC 10 + ½ your level + your TAM), and the first time each [Round] that an opponent starts its turn in or moves into a square occupied by one of your Firewalls, it takes [Electricity] damage equal to your level.

3rd Circle – Buffering…EX: When an [Encounter] starts, you begin to generate 3 temporary hit points per Proxy you control at the beginning of your turn each [Round] until the end of the [Encounter]. Temporary hit points gained from this ability stack with themselves up to a total of three times your character level, though they still don’t stack with other sources.

4th Circle – HackEX: You gain the ability to create Malware Proxies. If a Malware Proxy you control is adjacent to an opponent at the end of your turn, you may cause that opponent to become [Entangled] until the beginning of your next turn unless it makes a successful Fortitude save (DC 10 + ½ your level + your TAM). Each of your Malware Proxies can use this ability once per [Round] and you may only inflict this save on any given opponent once per [Round].

In addition, choose one of the following abilities. This choice is permanent.

  • Worm: If a Malware Proxy you control is adjacent to an opponent at the end of your turn, you may deal damage equal to your TAM to that opponent. Each of your Malware Proxies can use this ability once per [Round], and if a single opponent takes damage from multiple Malware Proxies at the same time, this damage is dealt as a single total, rather than a number of separate instances.
  • DDoS: If an opponent has failed a save from the Hack ability in the previous [Round] then each subsequent [Round] that your Malware is adjacent to them at the end of your turn, the Fortitude save that they inflict will have different effects upon failure based on the last condition inflicted on them by this ability and the number of Malware adjacent to them. The requirements and results of these additional effects are listed below.
    • [Entangled] & 2 adjacent Malware: The creature becomes [Entangled] and [Slowed].
    • [Slowed] & 4 adjacent Malware: The creature becomes [Entangled], [Slowed], and [Nauseated].
    • [Nauseated] & 6 adjacent Malware: The creature becomes [Paralyzed]. If the last save inflicted by Malware was succeeded against or the last condition inflicted was [Paralyzed], then the next save inflicted by Malware on that opponent will only inflict [Entangled] on a failed save as normal.
  • Trojan: Once per [Round], when two Malware Proxies you control are adjacent to an opponent at the end of your turn, that opponent gains [Vulnerability] to all damage for one [Round]. A successful Fortitude save (DC 10 + ½ your level + your TAM) negates the [Vulnerability].

5th Circle – Synch: You gain one of the following abilities. The choice is permanent:

  • GridlockEX: As part of a swift action, you may exchange squares with any one of your Mirror, Malware, or Port proxies. Alternately, you can exchange the squares of any two of your Proxies that are not Firewalls or Observers. This is a [Warp] effect. Twice times per [Encounter], you may charge your proxies with a move action before making any exchange of squares. After the exchanging is complete a chain reaction is set off, creating a number of lines equal to your number of proxies that deal 4 energy damage per level with the [Electricity] descriptor to all creatures they run through. These lines may be of any length as long as they start and end in the square of a Proxy within [Medium] range of yourself, and each Proxy may only have one start and end of a line in their square. Multiple lines overlapping the same squares do not deal additional damage.
  • Cloud ComputingEX: Twice per [Encounter], if you would use a supernatural or spell-like ability or Spell that is an Area of Effect ability with an instantaneous duration, instead of targeting that ability normally, you can create a duplicate of its effect centred on or originating from the space occupied by every Proxy you control within [Medium] range. If multiple instances of the ability overlap, they still affect any creatures caught in their area only once, and if the ability has a maximum number of affected creatures, this does not allow you to supersede that maximum.
  • LANEX: Twice per [Encounter] in place of an attack action, you may take a single melee attack through each one of your Mirror, Port, Jack, and Bug Proxies that you control. These attacks may not make critical hits and any effect that would activate as the result of a hit only activates on the first attack you make. You may not take a [Bonus attack] in the [Round] that you activate this ability.
  • ShutdownSLA: Once per [Encounter] you may focus fire through your Proxies for a single deadly blast. As a standard action, all Mirror, Port, Jack, and Bug Proxies you control fire on a single target within your [Medium] range, dealing damage equal to your character level for each Proxy that contributed to the blast. A successful Reflex save (DC equal to 10 + ½ your level + your TAM) halves the damage and prevents that attack from reducing your target below 1 hit point. This is a [Death] effect.

6th Circle – SLICeEX: The Temporary HP generated by your Proxies each [Round] at the beginning of your turn increases to 4 per Proxy and now stacks with itself up to a total of six times your character level. In addition, you gain upgrades to your Mirror and Observer Proxies’ functionalities.

  • Upload: You can now create Jack Proxies. Jack Proxies are identical to Observer Proxies, except that if the Jack is within [Medium] range of and has Line of Effect to you or a Proxy that is not an Observer, Jack, or Bug then you may take any action as if you were standing in a space occupied by the attuned ally.
  • Download: You can now create Port Proxies. Port Proxies are identical to Mirror Proxies, except that if an ally has Line of Effect and is within [Medium] range of the Proxy they may take any action as if they were standing in a space occupied by the Port. They do not control or affect the movement of the Port.
  • Intrusion: You can now create Bug Proxies. Bug Proxies are identical to Jack Proxies, except that they attune to opponents instead. Bugs are not created like other proxies in that you may only create one a [Round] or convert another Proxy into one once per [Round] though you may make this conversion as a part of any other Proxy conversion that you make that turn. Once created the Bug will attempt to attune to an opponent in [Medium] range. If the opponent fails a Will save (DC 10 + ½ your level + your TAM) then the Proxy attunes and follows them around undetectably as would a Jack. They are not aware of this unless you speak to them or act through them as you would through a Jack. If the attunement fails then the Proxy will immediately convert into a Jack that attunes to you. Once upon discovery of the Bug and once for every time you take an action from their space they may repeat the Will save to expel the Bug.

7th Circle – Version 9000EX: You and your Proxies may add the [Warp] descriptor to any movements they make. Your Firewall Proxies may now be any length between 5 ft and 30 ft that is divisible by 5. The Temporary HP generated by your Proxies each [Round] at the beginning of your turn increases to 7 per Proxy and now stacks with itself up to a total of seven times your character level.

5.17 Darkseeker

With a tragic backstory to avenge, a scar over your eyepatch which tells a thousand words, and a dark cloak, you are ready to harness the powers of pain and darkness in the name of your purpose. You do not fear pain, in fact, you embrace it, because you know the closer you are to the door of the afterlife, the more power you can siphon from your chtonic liege.

1st Circle – Revelry in the DarkEX: You have [Darkvision]. When your HP is below half of its current maximum, you deal additional damage with attacks equal to your KOM. When your HP is below a quarter of its current maximum, your bonus damage increases to your KOM multiplied by the number of circles you have in Darkseeker.

2nd Circle – The Blackened BladeEX: Whenever a creature is in your [Melee] range, it must target you if able when making melee attacks. If a creature is affected by multiple abilities which force targets like this, it may choose which of those targets to attack.

3rd Circle – Dark Fallen AngelEX: As long as your HP is below its current maximum, you gain the Fly movement mode. Whenever you take over 25 points of damage at once you may dispel a single effect of 3rd circle or lower within [Close] range. For every 15 points over 25, you may dispel an effect of a circle one higher (e.g. if you take 55 points you may dispel a 5th circle effect).

4th Circle – Nothing PersonnelEX: As a move action, [Teleport] a distance up to the difference between your current and maximum HP (rounded down to the next multiple of 5) to a space adjacent to an opponent. All opponents in your [Melee] range when you end the movement are [Flat-footed].

5th Circle – Unsealed Left EyeEX: As long as your HP is below half its current maximum, you ignore [Miss chance], gain [Blindsense] out to [Close] range, and gain a +3 bonus to attack rolls. This increases to +6 when your HP is below a quarter of its current maximum.

6th Circle – In Blackest NightEX: You gain 20% [Miss chance] against attacks by opponents who have ever dealt damage to you. This increases to 50% when your HP is below a quarter of its current maximum.

7th Circle – Dark Flame DragonEX: When your HP is at 10 or less, you gain [Greater resistance] to all damage, can make melee attacks freely out to [Medium] range, and gain a +7 bonus to all saves.

5.18 Defender

Special: Dwarves may switch one of their Tracks for Defender without using their multiclass

A key part of the Dwarven army is the Defender, a type of heavily armoured, tower shield-wielding warrior that forms the centre of a Dwarven shield wall. These Defenders practice a variety of techniques to protect their allies in battle and strengthen their own defence. While this is primarily a fighting style of Dwarves, members of other races who share the philosophy that a good defence is as good as an offence may also practice the style.

1st Circle – Born Underground, Suckled from a Teat of StoneEX: You are a naturally defensive fighter, and can even defend your allies that are within reach. Your natural weapons gain the [Parrying] and [Guardian] properties if they do not already have them. Your weapons possess the [Parrying] and [Guardian] properties while you wield them, if they do not already have them.

Once per [Round] per circle you possess from this track, as a free action, you can protect one ally within your [Melee] range until the start of their next turn. That ally’s natural weapons gain the [Parrying] and [Guardian] properties if they do not already have them. Their weapons possess the [Parrying] and [Guardian] properties while they wield them, if they do not already have them.

When you gain your 4th circle in this track, whenever you or an ally you have protected with this circle’s ability use the [Parrying] property, damage is reduced by that character’s level, instead of their KDM. Your, and that of your protected allies, deflection bonus to AC from the [Guardian] property increases to +2.

When you gain your 6th circle in this track, you or an ally you have protected may use the [Parrying] property as a free action twice per [Round]. Also, you and your protected allies’ deflection bonus to AC from the [Guardian] property increases to +3.

2nd Circle – Raised in the DarkEX: Whenever a creature is in your [Melee] range, it must target you if able when making melee attacks. The first instance of this ability to apply against a given creature over¬rides subsequent instances, so the first Defender to arrive is the mandatory target until he leaves, even if a second Defender also engages the same foe at a later time. If multiple instances of this ability ap¬ply at the same time against a given creature, that creature may choose which Defender to target. These rules also apply when an enemy is also in the [Melee] range of a Knight with Valiant Challenge.

3rd Circle – The Safety of Our Mountain HomeEX: You gain [Immunity] to [Fear]. You also gain a bonus to your Armour Class equal to +1 per ally in your [Melee] range.

4th Circle – Skin Made of IronEX: As an immediate action, you can attempt to intercept a ranged attack, spell, supernatural ability, or spell-like ability that would target or affect an ally within your [Melee] range. That ally can choose to replace its Armour Class with yours for the purposes of that attack, or replace its bonus to any saves it needs to make with your bonus to that save.

5th Circle – Steel in Our BonesEX: Your [Melee] range is doubled. Also, you gain [Damage reduction] equal to your level.

6th Circle – To Dig and Dig Makes Us FreeEX: You gain [Immunity] to [Binding] effects and those with the [Mind affecting] descriptor.

7th Circle – COME ON BROTHERS, SING WITH ME!EX: Once per [Encounter], as a free action you may gain [Immunity] to all damage until the start of your next turn.

5.19 Diamond Mind

In monasteries across the world and the dojos of Kamigawa, people forsake the way of the fist, but still wish to use the monastic methods of fighting with their weapons. These warriors of the Diamond Mind discipline centre themselves with constant meditation, so they can have a clear mind on the battlefield, and with this crystallised concentration they can perform amazing feats of swiftness and dexterity.

1st Circle – Moment of Perfect MindEX: Twice per [Encounter] when you make a saving throw, you may use your Perception modifier instead of the save modifier. You may only do this once per type of save (Fortitude, Reflex, Will) per [Encounter].

2nd Circle – Stance of AlacrityEX: You may make an additional attack of opportunity every [Round].

3rd Circle – Insightful StrikeEX: During an attack action, you may make a Perception check against an opponent in [Melee] range before your attack rolls. If it is successful, you may use the result of your Perception check in place of the normal damage any attack against that opponent would do this [Round] (including all modifiers). When you gain your 5th circle in Diamond Mind, you can do this to two opponents.

4th Circle – Rapid CounterEX: When you make an attack of opportunity, as an immediate action you may make an additional attack against the same target.

5th Circle – Pearl of Black DoubtEX: At the start of your turn, you may choose to forgo the benefits of Stance of Alacrity. Instead, every time an attack misses you, you gain a +2 bonus to AC until the start of your next turn.

6th Circle – Diamond ClarityEX: Stance of Alacrity grants an additional attack of opportunity (for a total of three), and when you use Rapid Counter, you may make a third attack against the target.

7th Circle – Time Stands StillEX: Once per [Encounter], when you make an attack action, immediately make another one.

5.20 Divination

Divination is the magic of finding things out, while Diviners are best known as seers – which is possible using divination ritual spells, they are also capable of a wide variety of things. In addition to short glimpses into the future in battle, they can sense danger, scry on other locations and creatures and can see straight through many forms of concealment.

1st Circle – One VisionSLA: You gain [Ghostwise sight] out to your close range. At the start of each [Round], choose attack rolls, skill checks or saving throws, and roll a d20 and note down the result. Use that result for the first roll you make of that type this [Round].

2nd Circle – Long SightSLA: You may cast clairaudience/clairvoyance at will, as the spell, except with a range of [Long]. You may target any space within [Long] range you can pinpoint, even if you are unfamiliar with it (for example if you know there is a room on the other side of a wall but you don’t know what is in there). When you reach your 3rd circle in Divination, this improves to the normal range of the spell.
